{"hepatitis enum_articles": "202", "hepatitis e": [{"archive_id": "7988324", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Burkina Faso", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7988324", "date": "2019-12-06 17:31:56", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (04): (OMAHEKE)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2019\nSource: Namibia Press Agency [edited]\nhttps://www.namibian.com.na/86195/read/100-hepatitis-E-cases-in-Omaheke\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services and other stakeholders at Gobabis are working around the clock to curb the spread of hepatitis E in the region. Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Responding to questions emailed to him by Nampa [Namibia Press Agency], Omaheke health director Jeremiah Shikulo said regional and district health emergency committees have been activated and are in full operation, leading and coordinating the outbreak response process with other line ministries.\n\n\"The Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry has provided 4 water tanks to the community of Kanaan, which the Gobabis municipality are refilling on a regular basis. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (03) 20190705.6554114\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02) 20190221.6329433\nHepatitis E - China (02): (Hong Kong) human, rat virus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7752960", "date": "2019-12-06 17:31:56", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (04): (OMAHEKE)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2019\nSource: Namibia Press Agency [edited]\nhttps://www.namibian.com.na/86195/read/100-hepatitis-E-cases-in-Omaheke\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services and other stakeholders at Gobabis are working around the clock to curb the spread of hepatitis E in the region. Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Responding to questions emailed to him by Nampa [Namibia Press Agency], Omaheke health director Jeremiah Shikulo said regional and district health emergency committees have been activated and are in full operation, leading and coordinating the outbreak response process with other line ministries.\n\n\"The Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry has provided 4 water tanks to the community of Kanaan, which the Gobabis municipality are refilling on a regular basis. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - USA: zoonosis, undercooked pork, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7038310", "date": "2019-12-06 17:31:56", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (04): (OMAHEKE)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2019\nSource: Namibia Press Agency [edited]\nhttps://www.namibian.com.na/86195/read/100-hepatitis-E-cases-in-Omaheke\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services and other stakeholders at Gobabis are working around the clock to curb the spread of hepatitis E in the region. Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Responding to questions emailed to him by Nampa [Namibia Press Agency], Omaheke health director Jeremiah Shikulo said regional and district health emergency committees have been activated and are in full operation, leading and coordinating the outbreak response process with other line ministries.\n\n\"The Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry has provided 4 water tanks to the community of Kanaan, which the Gobabis municipality are refilling on a regular basis. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (03) 20190705.6554114\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02) 20190221.6329433\nHepatitis E - Namibia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6946093", "date": "2019-12-06 17:31:56", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (04): (OMAHEKE)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Nov 2019\nSource: Namibia Press Agency [edited]\nhttps://www.namibian.com.na/86195/read/100-hepatitis-E-cases-in-Omaheke\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services and other stakeholders at Gobabis are working around the clock to curb the spread of hepatitis E in the region. Since the 1st case in the Omaheke region was reported in December 2017, about 137 other cases have been confirmed between March and November 2019. Out of the notified cases, one death has been recorded.\n\nMost of the reported cases in the region are from Gobabis, mainly from the Kanaan C informal settlement, where 123 cases were reported. This is as a result of a lack of clean drinking water, lack of sanitation facilities, and open-air defecation in the settlement. Responding to questions emailed to him by Nampa [Namibia Press Agency], Omaheke health director Jeremiah Shikulo said regional and district health emergency committees have been activated and are in full operation, leading and coordinating the outbreak response process with other line ministries.\n\n\"The Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry has provided 4 water tanks to the community of Kanaan, which the Gobabis municipality are refilling on a regular basis. Water purification tablets are also being distributed to households on a daily basis by community health workers,\" he added. The municipality has likewise given Kanaan C informal residents permission to build their own affordable temporary toilets.\n\nAmong other attempts to combat hepatitis E in the region, campaigns on how to properly clean water containers, screening pregnant women for the virus, and health education through community health workers have been conducted at Kanaan C. Five clean-up campaigns have also been held at the informal settlement, with another one set for tomorrow [6 Dec 2019].\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, usually as a result of poor sanitation. The disease was declared an outbreak on [14 Dec 2017] by the health ministry.\n\n[Byline: Elvi Haihambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (03) 20190705.6554114\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02) 20190221.6329433\nHepatitis E - Namibia (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6696423", "date": "2019-02-02 17:28:54", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA: (OMAHEKE)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: New Era [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/namibia/contingency-measures-hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-gobabis\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services, together with other stakeholders in Gobabis, have been working around the clock to come up with the regional response plan that will mitigate effects of a hepatitis E outbreak in town. Since the 1st case was reported in December 2018 -- a pregnant woman who has since miscarried -- 6 other cases have recently been confirmed out of the suspected 25, and the figure keeps rising steadily.\n\nMost of the reported cases are coming from informal settlements with poor sanitation, especially Kanaan C, whose residents have no access to clean water and toilets, which is why the regional directorate of health has been meeting with officials from the town council, regional council, and office of the governor to see how fast they could provide these key services to the said settlement.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer for Omaheke Region, Dr Leonard Kabongo, the emergency regional management meetings held Tuesday and Wednesday, 29-30 Jan 2019, yielded favourable fruits towards the mitigation of hepatitis E in the affected areas. Kabongo said they planned to install three 10 000 L [2642 gal] clean-water tanks and 10 portable toilets yesterday afternoon [Wed 30 Jan 2019] in Kanaan C, where most of the cases originated from.\n\n\"We are probably going to purchase and install more, but we will see how the budget will allow,\" he said. Kabongo has also revealed that his directorate has sent health-extension workers to the affected settlements, and especially to the affected households, to conduct informative meetings.\n\nThey will also start with the distribution of water purification tablets to the affected communities. In addition, there will be a clean-up campaign on Sat 9 Feb 2019 in the said areas, and Kabongo is calling on stakeholders to come on board and assist with necessary tools and equipment as well as trucks to add to the 2 availed by town council.\n\nHepatitis E, a liver disease mostly associated with poor sanitation, was reported in 2018 in Windhoek and Omusati Region, respectively.\n\n[Byline: Hileni Mwandingi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nHepatitis E - Central African Republic: (OP) 20181207.6191940\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh (02): (CG) 20181120.6154576\nHepatitis E - Nepal: (DO, KT) 20170624.5128824\nHepatitis E - Niger (06): (DF) fatal, pregnant women 20170620.5118509\nHepatitis E - Niger (05): (DF) fatal, pregnant women 20170613.5102098\nHepatitis E - India: (JK) contaminated water 20170612.5099614\n.................................................sb/ll/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-31 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2029-01-30 20:19:00", "2019-01-30 00:00:00", "2019-02-09 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Omaheke Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kabongo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omusati Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gobabis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kanaan C", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6688181", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis A and E - India: (PB) waterborne", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6688181", "date": "2019-02-02 17:28:54", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA: (OMAHEKE)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: New Era [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/namibia/contingency-measures-hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-gobabis\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services, together with other stakeholders in Gobabis, have been working around the clock to come up with the regional response plan that will mitigate effects of a hepatitis E outbreak in town. Since the 1st case was reported in December 2018 -- a pregnant woman who has since miscarried -- 6 other cases have recently been confirmed out of the suspected 25, and the figure keeps rising steadily.\n\nMost of the reported cases are coming from informal settlements with poor sanitation, especially Kanaan C, whose residents have no access to clean water and toilets, which is why the regional directorate of health has been meeting with officials from the town council, regional council, and office of the governor to see how fast they could provide these key services to the said settlement.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer for Omaheke Region, Dr Leonard Kabongo, the emergency regional management meetings held Tuesday and Wednesday, 29-30 Jan 2019, yielded favourable fruits towards the mitigation of hepatitis E in the affected areas. Kabongo said they planned to install three 10 000 L [2642 gal] clean-water tanks and 10 portable toilets yesterday afternoon [Wed 30 Jan 2019] in Kanaan C, where most of the cases originated from.\n\n\"We are probably going to purchase and install more, but we will see how the budget will allow,\" he said. Kabongo has also revealed that his directorate has sent health-extension workers to the affected settlements, and especially to the affected households, to conduct informative meetings.\n\nThey will also start with the distribution of water purification tablets to the affected communities. In addition, there will be a clean-up campaign on Sat 9 Feb 2019 in the said areas, and Kabongo is calling on stakeholders to come on board and assist with necessary tools and equipment as well as trucks to add to the 2 availed by town council.\n\nHepatitis E, a liver disease mostly associated with poor sanitation, was reported in 2018 in Windhoek and Omusati Region, respectively.\n\n[Byline: Hileni Mwandingi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nHepatitis E - Central African Republic: (OP) 20181207.6191940\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh (02): (CG) 20181120.6154576\nHepatitis E - China: (Hong Kong) human, rat virus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6470165", "date": "2019-02-02 17:28:54", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA: (OMAHEKE)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: New Era [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/namibia/contingency-measures-hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-gobabis\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Social Services, together with other stakeholders in Gobabis, have been working around the clock to come up with the regional response plan that will mitigate effects of a hepatitis E outbreak in town. Since the 1st case was reported in December 2018 -- a pregnant woman who has since miscarried -- 6 other cases have recently been confirmed out of the suspected 25, and the figure keeps rising steadily.\n\nMost of the reported cases are coming from informal settlements with poor sanitation, especially Kanaan C, whose residents have no access to clean water and toilets, which is why the regional directorate of health has been meeting with officials from the town council, regional council, and office of the governor to see how fast they could provide these key services to the said settlement.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer for Omaheke Region, Dr Leonard Kabongo, the emergency regional management meetings held Tuesday and Wednesday, 29-30 Jan 2019, yielded favourable fruits towards the mitigation of hepatitis E in the affected areas. Kabongo said they planned to install three 10 000 L [2642 gal] clean-water tanks and 10 portable toilets yesterday afternoon [Wed 30 Jan 2019] in Kanaan C, where most of the cases originated from.\n\n\"We are probably going to purchase and install more, but we will see how the budget will allow,\" he said. Kabongo has also revealed that his directorate has sent health-extension workers to the affected settlements, and especially to the affected households, to conduct informative meetings.\n\nThey will also start with the distribution of water purification tablets to the affected communities. In addition, there will be a clean-up campaign on Sat 9 Feb 2019 in the said areas, and Kabongo is calling on stakeholders to come on board and assist with necessary tools and equipment as well as trucks to add to the 2 availed by town council.\n\nHepatitis E, a liver disease mostly associated with poor sanitation, was reported in 2018 in Windhoek and Omusati Region, respectively.\n\n[Byline: Hileni Mwandingi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Acute epidemic hepatitis E is attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nOmaheke, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25624]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nHepatitis E - Central African Republic: (OP) 20181207.6191940\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh (02): (CG) 20181120.6154576\nHepatitis E - Central African Republic: (OP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6191940", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. According to Chittagong Civil Surgeon (CCS) office sources, over 300 people infected by HEV were given treatment in Bangladesh Institute of Tropical and Infectious Disease in Fauzderhat area of Chittagong since April 2018.\n\nUnder this circumstance, a team from Institute of Infectious Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) visited Halishahar area and collected blood samples from 25 affected people on May 3, said CCS, adding that they also collected the sample of drinking water.\n\nContacted, Dr SM Ali Haider, assistant professor of Gastroenterology of Chittagong Medical College Hospital, said people are infected by hepatitis E virus through water and food. \"In most cases, supporting treatment as well as complete rest and taking pure water can cure a patient, but sometimes it may turn fatal,\" he said. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 percent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 percent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 percent are common in some age groups. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3449]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (08): (OS) more cases 20180613.5854954\nHepatitis E - Namibia (07): (OS) fatal 20180530.5828842\nHepatitis E - Namibia (06): (KH) fatal 20180418.5756055\nHepatitis E - Germany 20180417.5751275\nHepatitis E - Namibia (05): (KH) fatal 20180228.5656294\nHepatitis E - Japan: transfusion, fatal 20180227.5653008\nHepatitis E - Namibia (04): (KH) fatal 20180213.5626670\nHepatitis E - Namibia (03): (KH) fatal 20180127.5585264\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02): (KH) fatal 20180117.5566623\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (KH) fatal 20180106.5542173\n2017\n----\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (Windhoek) 20171225.5522167\nHepatitis E - Nigeria (04): (BO) 20171120.5455477\nHepatitis E - Niger (07): (DF) 20171020.5393925\nHepatitis E - UK (03): gt 3, European sausage 20170821.5264392\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh: bloodborne risk 20170819.5261528\nHepatitis E - Nigeria (03): (BO) IDP camp 20170814.5244528\nHepatitis E - Africa: (Lake Chad Basin) 20170810.5241448\nHepatitis E - Nigeria (02): (BO) WHO 20170712.5168641\nHepatitis E - Europe (02): 2005-2015 20170629.5140079\nHepatitis E - Nigeria (BO) 20170628.5136977\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh (02): (CG)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6154576", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. According to Chittagong Civil Surgeon (CCS) office sources, over 300 people infected by HEV were given treatment in Bangladesh Institute of Tropical and Infectious Disease in Fauzderhat area of Chittagong since April 2018.\n\nUnder this circumstance, a team from Institute of Infectious Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) visited Halishahar area and collected blood samples from 25 affected people on May 3, said CCS, adding that they also collected the sample of drinking water.\n\nContacted, Dr SM Ali Haider, assistant professor of Gastroenterology of Chittagong Medical College Hospital, said people are infected by hepatitis E virus through water and food. \"In most cases, supporting treatment as well as complete rest and taking pure water can cure a patient, but sometimes it may turn fatal,\" he said. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 percent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 percent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 percent are common in some age groups. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3449]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (11)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6119131", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. China: (HK) human, rat virus, 1st rep", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6057342", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. According to Chittagong Civil Surgeon (CCS) office sources, over 300 people infected by HEV were given treatment in Bangladesh Institute of Tropical and Infectious Disease in Fauzderhat area of Chittagong since April 2018.\n\nUnder this circumstance, a team from Institute of Infectious Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) visited Halishahar area and collected blood samples from 25 affected people on May 3, said CCS, adding that they also collected the sample of drinking water.\n\nContacted, Dr SM Ali Haider, assistant professor of Gastroenterology of Chittagong Medical College Hospital, said people are infected by hepatitis E virus through water and food. \"In most cases, supporting treatment as well as complete rest and taking pure water can cure a patient, but sometimes it may turn fatal,\" he said. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 percent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 percent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 percent are common in some age groups. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3449]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (09): (ER) more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5890600", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. According to Chittagong Civil Surgeon (CCS) office sources, over 300 people infected by HEV were given treatment in Bangladesh Institute of Tropical and Infectious Disease in Fauzderhat area of Chittagong since April 2018.\n\nUnder this circumstance, a team from Institute of Infectious Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) visited Halishahar area and collected blood samples from 25 affected people on May 3, said CCS, adding that they also collected the sample of drinking water.\n\nContacted, Dr SM Ali Haider, assistant professor of Gastroenterology of Chittagong Medical College Hospital, said people are infected by hepatitis E virus through water and food. \"In most cases, supporting treatment as well as complete rest and taking pure water can cure a patient, but sometimes it may turn fatal,\" he said. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 percent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 percent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 percent are common in some age groups. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3449]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh: (CG) contaminated water susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5878210", "date": "2018-06-27 12:51:44", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - BANGLADESH: (CHITTAGONG) CONTAMINATED WATER SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jun 2018\nSource: The Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.thedailystar.net/city/hepatitis-e-outbreak-hits-port-city-1595317\n\n\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus [HEV] in Chittagong city's Halishahar and Agrabad areas for the last 3 months has put the lives of the residents at high risk. According to sources in the area, at least 3 people died in the last week since 17 Jun 2018, while over 300 people have been affected in the last 3 months.\n\nIt is suspected that there might have been leakage in Chittagong Water Supply and Sewage Authority (CWASA) pipeline. \"We have heard that the CWASA pipeline and sewerage line have mingled during the road development works in the area,\" said a family member of an affected person, adding, \"The authorities should check it well.\"\n\nDr Selim Akter Chowdhury, chief medical officer of Chittagong City Corporation (CCC), confirmed to The Daily Star that 3 people in Halishahar area died due to acute hepatitis in the last week [week of 18 Jun 2018]. According to Chittagong Civil Surgeon (CCS) office sources, over 300 people infected by HEV were given treatment in Bangladesh Institute of Tropical and Infectious Disease in Fauzderhat area of Chittagong since April 2018.\n\nUnder this circumstance, a team from Institute of Infectious Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) visited Halishahar area and collected blood samples from 25 affected people on May 3, said CCS, adding that they also collected the sample of drinking water.\n\nContacted, Dr SM Ali Haider, assistant professor of Gastroenterology of Chittagong Medical College Hospital, said people are infected by hepatitis E virus through water and food. \"In most cases, supporting treatment as well as complete rest and taking pure water can cure a patient, but sometimes it may turn fatal,\" he said. A patient out of 100 may die in HEV infection,\" he added.\n\nAgrabad and Halishahar areas regularly go under water during high tide, and so the underground water tanks of the houses may be contaminated with tidal water, said Dr Azizur Rahaman Siddique, Chittagong Civil Surgeon. Tidal water is contaminated in many ways including industrial effluents and human waste, he said.\n\nContacted, AKM Fazlullah, managing director of Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (CWASA) also held the tidal water responsible for the outbreak of jaundice in Agrabad and Halishahar areas. He denied the allegation of presence of HEV in water supplied by CWASA. \"If CWASA water was contaminated by HEV, people residing in 80 percent areas of the city would have been affected,\" he said\n\nFazlullah, however, said they regularly check the pipeline of CWASA for leakage, but \"no such incident\" was traced so far in the areas.\n\nCCC chief medical officer Selim Akter Chowdhury, however, said he asked his officials to find out the reason of the death of people in the areas. \"I have heard that they were suffering from jaundice. We are looking into it,\" he said.\n\n[Byline: Arun Bikash Dey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries is zoonotic and does not generally cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 percent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 percent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 percent are common in some age groups. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3449]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (08): (OS) more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5854954", "date": "2018-01-27 11:40:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (03): (KHOMAS) FATAL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Jan 2017 21:52:10\nSource: Xin Hua Net [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/25/c_136924873.htm\n\n\nHepatitis E case in Windhoek's informal sector have risen to 490, Namibia's health ministry said [Thu 25 Jan 2018], while blaming poor sanitation for fueling the spread of diseases. Health Minister Bernard Haufiku told a media conference that to date the outbreak has caused 2 maternal deaths, with majority of the cases coming from Havana and Goreangab settlements. \"The outbreak control and disease prevention activities are still ongoing, such as coordination, surveillance, case detection and management, wash and environmental health and social mobilization,\" he said.\n\nDirector of Health Information and Research Directorate Puumue Katjiunjo told Xinhua that currently health centers in the city get cases of suspected hepatitis E on a daily basis. \"Currently we cannot say it has been contained but efforts to reduce and contain the disease are being employed by the health ministry with the assistance of NGO agencies,\" he said.\n\nThe ministry encouraged the community in affected areas to continue with preventative measures including purifying drinking water and practicing healthy sanitary exercises. Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. A representative from Windhoek's City Authorities told Xinhua that currently the city is rehabilitating old toilets and cleaning up communities to assist in the prevention of further disease outbreaks.\n\nNamibia experienced its 1st hepatitis E outbreak in 1983 in Rundu, where 9 cases were confirmed, and the last outbreak was experienced in 1995-1996 also in Rundu. United Nations Resident Coordinator to Namibia Kiki Gbeho on [Thu 25 Jan 2017] said the UN is ready to assist the Namibian government's response to the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Yurou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 per cent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 per cent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 per cent are common in some age groups. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for the hepatitis E virus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html).\n\nA map of (Khomas Hochland, NA.40, Namibia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5602. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02): (KH) fatal 20180117.5566623\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (KH) fatal 20180106.5542173\n2017\n----\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (Windhoek) 20171225.5522167\nHepatitis E - Chad (02): (SA) WHO 20170125.4791758\nHepatitis E - Chad: (SA) effect in pregnancy 20170105.4742073\n.................................................ll/ec/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-01-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Havana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NA.40", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5756055", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Namibia (06): (KH) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5756055", "date": "2018-01-27 11:40:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (03): (KHOMAS) FATAL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Jan 2017 21:52:10\nSource: Xin Hua Net [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/25/c_136924873.htm\n\n\nHepatitis E case in Windhoek's informal sector have risen to 490, Namibia's health ministry said [Thu 25 Jan 2018], while blaming poor sanitation for fueling the spread of diseases. Health Minister Bernard Haufiku told a media conference that to date the outbreak has caused 2 maternal deaths, with majority of the cases coming from Havana and Goreangab settlements. \"The outbreak control and disease prevention activities are still ongoing, such as coordination, surveillance, case detection and management, wash and environmental health and social mobilization,\" he said.\n\nDirector of Health Information and Research Directorate Puumue Katjiunjo told Xinhua that currently health centers in the city get cases of suspected hepatitis E on a daily basis. \"Currently we cannot say it has been contained but efforts to reduce and contain the disease are being employed by the health ministry with the assistance of NGO agencies,\" he said.\n\nThe ministry encouraged the community in affected areas to continue with preventative measures including purifying drinking water and practicing healthy sanitary exercises. Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. A representative from Windhoek's City Authorities told Xinhua that currently the city is rehabilitating old toilets and cleaning up communities to assist in the prevention of further disease outbreaks.\n\nNamibia experienced its 1st hepatitis E outbreak in 1983 in Rundu, where 9 cases were confirmed, and the last outbreak was experienced in 1995-1996 also in Rundu. United Nations Resident Coordinator to Namibia Kiki Gbeho on [Thu 25 Jan 2017] said the UN is ready to assist the Namibian government's response to the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Yurou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 per cent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 per cent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 per cent are common in some age groups. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for the hepatitis E virus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html).\n\nA map of (Khomas Hochland, NA.40, Namibia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5602. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Namibia (02): (KH) fatal 20180117.5566623\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (KH) fatal 20180106.5542173\n2017\n----\nHepatitis E - Namibia: (Windhoek) 20171225.5522167\nHepatitis E - Niger (03): (DF) fatal, pregnant women 20170506.5017895\nHepatitis E - Niger (02): (DF) fatalities, IDP 20170426.4996912\nHepatitis E - Niger: fatalities 20170423.4989073\nHepatitis E - Chad (03): (SA) 20170226.4866244\nHepatitis E - Chad (02): (SA) WHO 20170125.4791758\nHepatitis E - Chad: (SA) effect in pregnancy 20170105.4742073\n.................................................ll/ec/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-01-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Havana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NA.40", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5751275", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - Germany", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5751275", "date": "2018-01-27 11:40:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (03): (KHOMAS) FATAL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Jan 2017 21:52:10\nSource: Xin Hua Net [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/25/c_136924873.htm\n\n\nHepatitis E case in Windhoek's informal sector have risen to 490, Namibia's health ministry said [Thu 25 Jan 2018], while blaming poor sanitation for fueling the spread of diseases. Health Minister Bernard Haufiku told a media conference that to date the outbreak has caused 2 maternal deaths, with majority of the cases coming from Havana and Goreangab settlements. \"The outbreak control and disease prevention activities are still ongoing, such as coordination, surveillance, case detection and management, wash and environmental health and social mobilization,\" he said.\n\nDirector of Health Information and Research Directorate Puumue Katjiunjo told Xinhua that currently health centers in the city get cases of suspected hepatitis E on a daily basis. \"Currently we cannot say it has been contained but efforts to reduce and contain the disease are being employed by the health ministry with the assistance of NGO agencies,\" he said.\n\nThe ministry encouraged the community in affected areas to continue with preventative measures including purifying drinking water and practicing healthy sanitary exercises. Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. A representative from Windhoek's City Authorities told Xinhua that currently the city is rehabilitating old toilets and cleaning up communities to assist in the prevention of further disease outbreaks.\n\nNamibia experienced its 1st hepatitis E outbreak in 1983 in Rundu, where 9 cases were confirmed, and the last outbreak was experienced in 1995-1996 also in Rundu. United Nations Resident Coordinator to Namibia Kiki Gbeho on [Thu 25 Jan 2017] said the UN is ready to assist the Namibian government's response to the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Yurou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 per cent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 per cent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 per cent are common in some age groups. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for the hepatitis E virus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html).\n\nA map of (Khomas Hochland, NA.40, Namibia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5602. - Health Minister Bernard Haufiku told a media conference that to date the outbreak has caused 2 maternal deaths, with majority of the cases coming from Havana and Goreangab settlements. \"The outbreak control and disease prevention activities are still ongoing, such as coordination, surveillance, case detection and management, wash and environmental health and social mobilization,\" he said.\n\nDirector of Health Information and Research Directorate Puumue Katjiunjo told Xinhua that currently health centers in the city get cases of suspected hepatitis E on a daily basis. \"Currently we cannot say it has been contained but efforts to reduce and contain the disease are being employed by the health ministry with the assistance of NGO agencies,\" he said.\n\nThe ministry encouraged the community in affected areas to continue with preventative measures including purifying drinking water and practicing healthy sanitary exercises. Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. A representative from Windhoek's City Authorities told Xinhua that currently the city is rehabilitating old toilets and cleaning up communities to assist in the prevention of further disease outbreaks.\n\nNamibia experienced its 1st hepatitis E outbreak in 1983 in Rundu, where 9 cases were confirmed, and the last outbreak was experienced in 1995-1996 also in Rundu. United Nations Resident Coordinator to Namibia Kiki Gbeho on [Thu 25 Jan 2017] said the UN is ready to assist the Namibian government's response to the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Yurou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Japan: transfusion, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5653008", "date": "2018-01-27 11:40:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NAMIBIA (03): (KHOMAS) FATAL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Jan 2017 21:52:10\nSource: Xin Hua Net [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/25/c_136924873.htm\n\n\nHepatitis E case in Windhoek's informal sector have risen to 490, Namibia's health ministry said [Thu 25 Jan 2018], while blaming poor sanitation for fueling the spread of diseases. Health Minister Bernard Haufiku told a media conference that to date the outbreak has caused 2 maternal deaths, with majority of the cases coming from Havana and Goreangab settlements. \"The outbreak control and disease prevention activities are still ongoing, such as coordination, surveillance, case detection and management, wash and environmental health and social mobilization,\" he said.\n\nDirector of Health Information and Research Directorate Puumue Katjiunjo told Xinhua that currently health centers in the city get cases of suspected hepatitis E on a daily basis. \"Currently we cannot say it has been contained but efforts to reduce and contain the disease are being employed by the health ministry with the assistance of NGO agencies,\" he said.\n\nThe ministry encouraged the community in affected areas to continue with preventative measures including purifying drinking water and practicing healthy sanitary exercises. Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. A representative from Windhoek's City Authorities told Xinhua that currently the city is rehabilitating old toilets and cleaning up communities to assist in the prevention of further disease outbreaks.\n\nNamibia experienced its 1st hepatitis E outbreak in 1983 in Rundu, where 9 cases were confirmed, and the last outbreak was experienced in 1995-1996 also in Rundu. United Nations Resident Coordinator to Namibia Kiki Gbeho on [Thu 25 Jan 2017] said the UN is ready to assist the Namibian government's response to the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Yurou]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of the hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. For example, genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 per cent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 per cent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 per cent are common in some age groups. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for the hepatitis E virus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html).\n\nA map of (Khomas Hochland, NA.40, Namibia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5602. - Poor sanitation has been blamed for fueling disease outbreaks in Namibia, with the health ministry saying 68 percent households in the country's informal settlements still practise open defecation. It also stated that 92 percent of households in the informal sector collect water from communal taps and 2 percent from unsafe water sources, compared with 6 percent that have household taps.\n\nKatjiunjo said that 55 percent of water samples collected at point of use tested positive for total coliforms, an indication of fecal contamination. Globally, 57 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. Many of the deaths are in pregnant women, characteristic of genotype 1.\n\nThe highest seroprevalence rates (number of persons in a population who test positive for the disease) are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. Over 60 per cent of all hepatitis E infections and 65 per cent of all hepatitis E deaths occur in East and South Asia, where seroprevalence rates of 25 per cent are common in some age groups. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for the hepatitis E virus (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html).\n\nA map of (Khomas Hochland, NA.40, Namibia): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5602. -
