Surveys have shown that 17% of adults in Germany have antibodies against the virus, meaning they became infected at some point; so do 14% in Austria, 4% in southern Italy, and 27% in the Netherlands. One Dutch study found that antibody levels in people aged 18 to 21 dropped from almost 20% in 1995 to less than 5% in 2000, then rose again to 13% in 2011, which suggests the infection is re-emerging, says Zaaijer, a co-author on the study.\n\nBlood and blood products account for at least some of the new infections. One study suggested that 1200 blood components containing the virus are transfused each year in the United Kingdom, and roughly one in 1000 blood donors in the Netherlands carries the virus. (By contrast, a recent U.S. study found the virus's genetic material in just one donor per 9500.)\n\nA much bigger risk factor is the consumption of sausages and other pork products. Hepatitis E has been shown to be ubiquitous in swine herds in many European countries. Most animals become infected without getting sick between 3 and 6 months after birth, when antibodies inherited from their mothers start to wane. And there's strong evidence that the virus is passed on to humans through pork. In one study, Wim van der Poel, a veterinary virologist at Wageningen University and Research Centre in the Netherlands, analyzed hepatitis E sequences found in Dutch blood donors between 2010 and 2015. \"When we looked for the closest sequence ever found, [it] was always a swine sequence from the same region,\" he says.\n\nWhat's unclear is which pork products carry the highest risk. In one region in the south of France, infections have been linked to consumption of figatellu, a pig liver sausage that's often eaten raw. Scientists are still trying to pinpoint which other products contain the virus. It's difficult to culture the virus from meat products, and looking directly for viral RNA is technically complicated; moreover, finding RNA does not mean the food contains intact virus that can infect a consumer. Meanwhile, some studies have also shown a risk from eating shellfish or fruit.\n\nIn the United States, in contrast, hepatitis E \"is very rare even in transplant patients and the immunosuppressed,\" says Jay Hoofnagle of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland. One theory is that U.S. residents eat less raw or undercooked pork. Another theory: Pigs in Europe may suffer from immune deficiencies because of some other infection. \"An HIV-like agent may cause pigs or wild boar to develop chronic HEV infection,\" Hoofnagle says.\n\nWith so many unknowns, controlling this silent epidemic is a challenge. Ireland already screens blood products for hepatitis E, and other countries are debating doing so. Like everything else involving the blood supply, \"it's a touchy subject,\" Pischke says. Screening is costly and may not make sense for the general population, which has little to fear from HEV, says Rainer Seitz, head of transfusion medicine at the Paul Ehrlich Institute in Langen, Germany, a federal institute responsible for blood safety. But he supports screening blood products before use in immunocompromised patients. The virus's apparent ubiquity in pork products and elsewhere in the environment also makes general blood screening questionable, Zaaijer says. \"It's like screening donors for flu in times of flu. The blood is safe, but the air isn't,\" he says. It's far more important to make food and water free of hepatitis E, he adds.\n\nOne way to do that would be to vaccinate pigs. A human vaccine has already been approved in China, and scientists think a swine vaccine is feasible as well. But getting pig farmers to adopt it would be difficult, Van der Poel predicts, because their animals don't get sick. And you'd have to be careful to vaccinate every last animal in a herd, Zaaijer adds; otherwise, the virus might just spread slowly, meaning that animals would get infected later in life, closer to slaughter, which might increase the risk in meat.\n\nReimar Johne, who studies hepatitis E at the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment in Berlin, is trying to find out how the virus can be inactivated in food. 20 minutes at 70 C [158 F] destroys it, but what about drying, smoking, or curing meat? To find out, Johne has started to make sausages in the lab himself. After adding a strain of hepatitis E, he can process the meat any way he wants and check whether viable virus survives. \"It's a bit artificial,\" he says. \"But for the moment, it's all we have.\"\n\n[Byline: Kai Kupferschmidt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is an excellent posting on the zoonotic genotype 3 strain of HEV. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nHepatitis E - France: 2013, raw pork stuffing 20151021.3733016\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked imported pork sausage, 2014 20150908.3631747\n2014\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked pork sausage 20141111.2946919\nHepatitis E - France: (VR) raw pork liver sausage 20141010.2850748\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4769936", "headline": "PRO> Hepatitis E - France (02): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4769936", "date": "2016-08-28 19:03:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - EUROPE: ZOONOTIC\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2016\nSource: Science Vol. 353, Issue 6302, pp. 862-863 [edited]\nhttp://science.sciencemag.org/content/353/6302/862.full\n\n\nAlmost immediately after a man received a new heart, his body began to reject it. To save the 58-year-old retired plumber from northern Germany, doctors replaced his blood plasma with donated plasma lacking the antibodies that targeted the donor organ. It worked, but 3 years later, it's clear that he received something else in the bargain: the hepatitis E virus (HEV).\n\nIt's a pathogen that most people get rid of easily without even getting sick. But the man was taking drugs that dampen his immune system to prevent another rejection of his heart. As a result, he can't clear the virus; it has been quietly replicating in his liver ever since. \"If that is not resolved, it leads to liver fibrosis, then liver cirrhosis, then death,\" Sven Pischke, his doctor at the University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, says matter-of-factly. \"That was a shock, of course,\" the patient says.\n\nPatients like him are a new challenge for European physicians. Until a few years ago, no one even knew they existed. Hepatitis E was seen as an exotic disease that travelers from India or Africa sometimes brought home. Now, it's clear that there's a silent epidemic of the virus at home, with an estimated 300 000 people infected annually in Germany alone. Most appear to catch it from eating pork, with blood and plasma transfusions playing a smaller role. The virus occurs in other developed countries as well -- including the USA, Japan, and Australia -- though infections appear to be much rarer there.\n\nScientists are still scrambling to understand the epidemiology of hepatitis E, but they know that in Europe, infection rates rival those for other major hepatitis pathogens (A, B, and C). Two questions are looming large: Should blood donations be screened for the virus? And what can be done to eliminate it from swine herds?\n\nResearchers suspected a new form of hepatitis in 1978, when hundreds of people in Jammu and Kashmir, in northern India, got sick -- and 4 men and 6 pregnant women died -- from what appeared to be a waterborne hepatitis virus. Similar but larger outbreaks followed in India, Pakistan, and China, killing thousands of people, many of them pregnant women. It wasn't until 1983 that Russian scientist Mikhail Balayan isolated the virus from his own stool after a gutsy self-experiment: He drank a cocktail of yogurt and stool samples from Soviet soldiers infected in Afghanistan. Hepatitis E became known as an important waterborne pathogen in Asia and Africa; 2 strains, named genotype 1 and 2, together kill an estimated 58 000 people per year.\n\nBut in 1997, scientists discovered that pigs in the American Midwest carried a new strain of the virus, which they named genotype 3. It was soon identified in European pigs as well, and surveys showed that many Europeans had antibodies to it, a sign they had been infected at some point in their lives. Genotype 3 was very different from its relatives: Pork, not dirty water, appeared to be its main transmission route, and it seemed not to cause any symptoms. \"Hepatitis E does not exist,\" says Hans Zaaijer, who heads the department of bloodborne infections at Sanquin, a nonprofit blood transfusion service in Amsterdam. \"These are 2 completely distinct diseases.\" (It's not clear whether genotype 3 might also spread in developing countries, hiding in the shadow of its more obvious relatives.)\n\nAlas, the new strain wasn't as innocuous as it seemed. In 2008, French researchers reported that in a group of 300 recent transplant patients, 14 had an acute hepatitis E infection. Six got rid of the virus quickly, but 8 couldn't seem to shake it. At Hannover Medical School in Germany, hepatitis specialist Heiner Wedemeyer couldn't believe it at first. \"We are one of the largest transplantation centers in Europe,\" he remembers thinking. \"We would have seen that.\" But when he started screening patients he soon found some that were chronically infected with hepatitis E, as did other clinics all over Europe. Patients had one thing in common: a weakened immune system.\n\nThere's not much doctors can do to help them. For transplant patients, one option is lowering the doses of immunosuppressive drugs to allow the immune system to regenerate, but this increases the risk of organ rejection. Doctors also use ribavirin, a drug approved for hepatitis C and several other viral infections. But there hasn't been a controlled trial yet, and ribavirin has serious side effects.\n\nThese patients are the visible part of a much wider epidemic. Surveys have shown that 17% of adults in Germany have antibodies against the virus, meaning they became infected at some point; so do 14% in Austria, 4% in southern Italy, and 27% in the Netherlands. One Dutch study found that antibody levels in people aged 18 to 21 dropped from almost 20% in 1995 to less than 5% in 2000, then rose again to 13% in 2011, which suggests the infection is re-emerging, says Zaaijer, a co-author on the study.\n\nBlood and blood products account for at least some of the new infections. One study suggested that 1200 blood components containing the virus are transfused each year in the United Kingdom, and roughly one in 1000 blood donors in the Netherlands carries the virus. (By contrast, a recent U.S. study found the virus's genetic material in just one donor per 9500.)\n\nA much bigger risk factor is the consumption of sausages and other pork products. Hepatitis E has been shown to be ubiquitous in swine herds in many European countries. Most animals become infected without getting sick between 3 and 6 months after birth, when antibodies inherited from their mothers start to wane. And there's strong evidence that the virus is passed on to humans through pork. In one study, Wim van der Poel, a veterinary virologist at Wageningen University and Research Centre in the Netherlands, analyzed hepatitis E sequences found in Dutch blood donors between 2010 and 2015. \"When we looked for the closest sequence ever found, [it] was always a swine sequence from the same region,\" he says.\n\nWhat's unclear is which pork products carry the highest risk. In one region in the south of France, infections have been linked to consumption of figatellu, a pig liver sausage that's often eaten raw. Scientists are still trying to pinpoint which other products contain the virus. It's difficult to culture the virus from meat products, and looking directly for viral RNA is technically complicated; moreover, finding RNA does not mean the food contains intact virus that can infect a consumer. Meanwhile, some studies have also shown a risk from eating shellfish or fruit.\n\nIn the United States, in contrast, hepatitis E \"is very rare even in transplant patients and the immunosuppressed,\" says Jay Hoofnagle of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland. One theory is that U.S. residents eat less raw or undercooked pork. Another theory: Pigs in Europe may suffer from immune deficiencies because of some other infection. \"An HIV-like agent may cause pigs or wild boar to develop chronic HEV infection,\" Hoofnagle says.\n\nWith so many unknowns, controlling this silent epidemic is a challenge. Ireland already screens blood products for hepatitis E, and other countries are debating doing so. Like everything else involving the blood supply, \"it's a touchy subject,\" Pischke says. Screening is costly and may not make sense for the general population, which has little to fear from HEV, says Rainer Seitz, head of transfusion medicine at the Paul Ehrlich Institute in Langen, Germany, a federal institute responsible for blood safety. But he supports screening blood products before use in immunocompromised patients. The virus's apparent ubiquity in pork products and elsewhere in the environment also makes general blood screening questionable, Zaaijer says. \"It's like screening donors for flu in times of flu. The blood is safe, but the air isn't,\" he says. It's far more important to make food and water free of hepatitis E, he adds.\n\nOne way to do that would be to vaccinate pigs. A human vaccine has already been approved in China, and scientists think a swine vaccine is feasible as well. But getting pig farmers to adopt it would be difficult, Van der Poel predicts, because their animals don't get sick. And you'd have to be careful to vaccinate every last animal in a herd, Zaaijer adds; otherwise, the virus might just spread slowly, meaning that animals would get infected later in life, closer to slaughter, which might increase the risk in meat.\n\nReimar Johne, who studies hepatitis E at the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment in Berlin, is trying to find out how the virus can be inactivated in food. 20 minutes at 70 C [158 F] destroys it, but what about drying, smoking, or curing meat? To find out, Johne has started to make sausages in the lab himself. After adding a strain of hepatitis E, he can process the meat any way he wants and check whether viable virus survives. \"It's a bit artificial,\" he says. \"But for the moment, it's all we have.\"\n\n[Byline: Kai Kupferschmidt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is an excellent posting on the zoonotic genotype 3 strain of HEV. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nHepatitis E - France: 2013, raw pork stuffing 20151021.3733016\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked imported pork sausage, 2014 20150908.3631747\n2014\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked pork sausage 20141111.2946919\nHepatitis E - France: (VR) raw pork liver sausage 20141010.2850748\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4763642", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4742073", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Chad: (SA) effect in pregnancy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4742073", "date": "2016-08-28 19:03:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - EUROPE: ZOONOTIC\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2016\nSource: Science Vol. 353, Issue 6302, pp. 862-863 [edited]\nhttp://science.sciencemag.org/content/353/6302/862.full\n\n\nAlmost immediately after a man received a new heart, his body began to reject it. To save the 58-year-old retired plumber from northern Germany, doctors replaced his blood plasma with donated plasma lacking the antibodies that targeted the donor organ. It worked, but 3 years later, it's clear that he received something else in the bargain: the hepatitis E virus (HEV).\n\nIt's a pathogen that most people get rid of easily without even getting sick. But the man was taking drugs that dampen his immune system to prevent another rejection of his heart. As a result, he can't clear the virus; it has been quietly replicating in his liver ever since. \"If that is not resolved, it leads to liver fibrosis, then liver cirrhosis, then death,\" Sven Pischke, his doctor at the University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, says matter-of-factly. \"That was a shock, of course,\" the patient says.\n\nPatients like him are a new challenge for European physicians. Until a few years ago, no one even knew they existed. Hepatitis E was seen as an exotic disease that travelers from India or Africa sometimes brought home. Now, it's clear that there's a silent epidemic of the virus at home, with an estimated 300 000 people infected annually in Germany alone. Most appear to catch it from eating pork, with blood and plasma transfusions playing a smaller role. The virus occurs in other developed countries as well -- including the USA, Japan, and Australia -- though infections appear to be much rarer there.\n\nScientists are still scrambling to understand the epidemiology of hepatitis E, but they know that in Europe, infection rates rival those for other major hepatitis pathogens (A, B, and C). Two questions are looming large: Should blood donations be screened for the virus? And what can be done to eliminate it from swine herds?\n\nResearchers suspected a new form of hepatitis in 1978, when hundreds of people in Jammu and Kashmir, in northern India, got sick -- and 4 men and 6 pregnant women died -- from what appeared to be a waterborne hepatitis virus. Similar but larger outbreaks followed in India, Pakistan, and China, killing thousands of people, many of them pregnant women. It wasn't until 1983 that Russian scientist Mikhail Balayan isolated the virus from his own stool after a gutsy self-experiment: He drank a cocktail of yogurt and stool samples from Soviet soldiers infected in Afghanistan. Hepatitis E became known as an important waterborne pathogen in Asia and Africa; 2 strains, named genotype 1 and 2, together kill an estimated 58 000 people per year.\n\nBut in 1997, scientists discovered that pigs in the American Midwest carried a new strain of the virus, which they named genotype 3. It was soon identified in European pigs as well, and surveys showed that many Europeans had antibodies to it, a sign they had been infected at some point in their lives. Genotype 3 was very different from its relatives: Pork, not dirty water, appeared to be its main transmission route, and it seemed not to cause any symptoms. \"Hepatitis E does not exist,\" says Hans Zaaijer, who heads the department of bloodborne infections at Sanquin, a nonprofit blood transfusion service in Amsterdam. \"These are 2 completely distinct diseases.\" (It's not clear whether genotype 3 might also spread in developing countries, hiding in the shadow of its more obvious relatives.)\n\nAlas, the new strain wasn't as innocuous as it seemed. In 2008, French researchers reported that in a group of 300 recent transplant patients, 14 had an acute hepatitis E infection. Six got rid of the virus quickly, but 8 couldn't seem to shake it. At Hannover Medical School in Germany, hepatitis specialist Heiner Wedemeyer couldn't believe it at first. \"We are one of the largest transplantation centers in Europe,\" he remembers thinking. \"We would have seen that.\" But when he started screening patients he soon found some that were chronically infected with hepatitis E, as did other clinics all over Europe. Patients had one thing in common: a weakened immune system.\n\nThere's not much doctors can do to help them. For transplant patients, one option is lowering the doses of immunosuppressive drugs to allow the immune system to regenerate, but this increases the risk of organ rejection. Doctors also use ribavirin, a drug approved for hepatitis C and several other viral infections. But there hasn't been a controlled trial yet, and ribavirin has serious side effects.\n\nThese patients are the visible part of a much wider epidemic. Surveys have shown that 17% of adults in Germany have antibodies against the virus, meaning they became infected at some point; so do 14% in Austria, 4% in southern Italy, and 27% in the Netherlands. One Dutch study found that antibody levels in people aged 18 to 21 dropped from almost 20% in 1995 to less than 5% in 2000, then rose again to 13% in 2011, which suggests the infection is re-emerging, says Zaaijer, a co-author on the study.\n\nBlood and blood products account for at least some of the new infections. One study suggested that 1200 blood components containing the virus are transfused each year in the United Kingdom, and roughly one in 1000 blood donors in the Netherlands carries the virus. (By contrast, a recent U.S. study found the virus's genetic material in just one donor per 9500.)\n\nA much bigger risk factor is the consumption of sausages and other pork products. Hepatitis E has been shown to be ubiquitous in swine herds in many European countries. Most animals become infected without getting sick between 3 and 6 months after birth, when antibodies inherited from their mothers start to wane. And there's strong evidence that the virus is passed on to humans through pork. In one study, Wim van der Poel, a veterinary virologist at Wageningen University and Research Centre in the Netherlands, analyzed hepatitis E sequences found in Dutch blood donors between 2010 and 2015. \"When we looked for the closest sequence ever found, [it] was always a swine sequence from the same region,\" he says.\n\nWhat's unclear is which pork products carry the highest risk. In one region in the south of France, infections have been linked to consumption of figatellu, a pig liver sausage that's often eaten raw. Scientists are still trying to pinpoint which other products contain the virus. It's difficult to culture the virus from meat products, and looking directly for viral RNA is technically complicated; moreover, finding RNA does not mean the food contains intact virus that can infect a consumer. Meanwhile, some studies have also shown a risk from eating shellfish or fruit.\n\nIn the United States, in contrast, hepatitis E \"is very rare even in transplant patients and the immunosuppressed,\" says Jay Hoofnagle of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland. One theory is that U.S. residents eat less raw or undercooked pork. Another theory: Pigs in Europe may suffer from immune deficiencies because of some other infection. \"An HIV-like agent may cause pigs or wild boar to develop chronic HEV infection,\" Hoofnagle says.\n\nWith so many unknowns, controlling this silent epidemic is a challenge. Ireland already screens blood products for hepatitis E, and other countries are debating doing so. Like everything else involving the blood supply, \"it's a touchy subject,\" Pischke says. Screening is costly and may not make sense for the general population, which has little to fear from HEV, says Rainer Seitz, head of transfusion medicine at the Paul Ehrlich Institute in Langen, Germany, a federal institute responsible for blood safety. But he supports screening blood products before use in immunocompromised patients. The virus's apparent ubiquity in pork products and elsewhere in the environment also makes general blood screening questionable, Zaaijer says. \"It's like screening donors for flu in times of flu. The blood is safe, but the air isn't,\" he says. It's far more important to make food and water free of hepatitis E, he adds.\n\nOne way to do that would be to vaccinate pigs. A human vaccine has already been approved in China, and scientists think a swine vaccine is feasible as well. But getting pig farmers to adopt it would be difficult, Van der Poel predicts, because their animals don't get sick. And you'd have to be careful to vaccinate every last animal in a herd, Zaaijer adds; otherwise, the virus might just spread slowly, meaning that animals would get infected later in life, closer to slaughter, which might increase the risk in meat.\n\nReimar Johne, who studies hepatitis E at the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment in Berlin, is trying to find out how the virus can be inactivated in food. 20 minutes at 70 C [158 F] destroys it, but what about drying, smoking, or curing meat? To find out, Johne has started to make sausages in the lab himself. After adding a strain of hepatitis E, he can process the meat any way he wants and check whether viable virus survives. \"It's a bit artificial,\" he says. \"But for the moment, it's all we have.\"\n\n[Byline: Kai Kupferschmidt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is an excellent posting on the zoonotic genotype 3 strain of HEV. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nHepatitis E - France: 2013, raw pork stuffing 20151021.3733016\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked imported pork sausage, 2014 20150908.3631747\n2014\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked pork sausage 20141111.2946919\nHepatitis E - France: (VR) raw pork liver sausage 20141010.2850748\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4461204", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Germany: gt 3, asymptomatic, 2011", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4461204", "date": "2016-08-28 19:03:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - EUROPE: ZOONOTIC\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2016\nSource: Science Vol. 353, Issue 6302, pp. 862-863 [edited]\nhttp://science.sciencemag.org/content/353/6302/862.full\n\n\nAlmost immediately after a man received a new heart, his body began to reject it. To save the 58-year-old retired plumber from northern Germany, doctors replaced his blood plasma with donated plasma lacking the antibodies that targeted the donor organ. It worked, but 3 years later, it's clear that he received something else in the bargain: the hepatitis E virus (HEV).\n\nIt's a pathogen that most people get rid of easily without even getting sick. But the man was taking drugs that dampen his immune system to prevent another rejection of his heart. As a result, he can't clear the virus; it has been quietly replicating in his liver ever since. \"If that is not resolved, it leads to liver fibrosis, then liver cirrhosis, then death,\" Sven Pischke, his doctor at the University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, says matter-of-factly. \"That was a shock, of course,\" the patient says.\n\nPatients like him are a new challenge for European physicians. Until a few years ago, no one even knew they existed. Hepatitis E was seen as an exotic disease that travelers from India or Africa sometimes brought home. Now, it's clear that there's a silent epidemic of the virus at home, with an estimated 300 000 people infected annually in Germany alone. Most appear to catch it from eating pork, with blood and plasma transfusions playing a smaller role. The virus occurs in other developed countries as well -- including the USA, Japan, and Australia -- though infections appear to be much rarer there.\n\nScientists are still scrambling to understand the epidemiology of hepatitis E, but they know that in Europe, infection rates rival those for other major hepatitis pathogens (A, B, and C). Two questions are looming large: Should blood donations be screened for the virus? And what can be done to eliminate it from swine herds?\n\nResearchers suspected a new form of hepatitis in 1978, when hundreds of people in Jammu and Kashmir, in northern India, got sick -- and 4 men and 6 pregnant women died -- from what appeared to be a waterborne hepatitis virus. Similar but larger outbreaks followed in India, Pakistan, and China, killing thousands of people, many of them pregnant women. It wasn't until 1983 that Russian scientist Mikhail Balayan isolated the virus from his own stool after a gutsy self-experiment: He drank a cocktail of yogurt and stool samples from Soviet soldiers infected in Afghanistan. Hepatitis E became known as an important waterborne pathogen in Asia and Africa; 2 strains, named genotype 1 and 2, together kill an estimated 58 000 people per year.\n\nBut in 1997, scientists discovered that pigs in the American Midwest carried a new strain of the virus, which they named genotype 3. It was soon identified in European pigs as well, and surveys showed that many Europeans had antibodies to it, a sign they had been infected at some point in their lives. Genotype 3 was very different from its relatives: Pork, not dirty water, appeared to be its main transmission route, and it seemed not to cause any symptoms. \"Hepatitis E does not exist,\" says Hans Zaaijer, who heads the department of bloodborne infections at Sanquin, a nonprofit blood transfusion service in Amsterdam. \"These are 2 completely distinct diseases.\" (It's not clear whether genotype 3 might also spread in developing countries, hiding in the shadow of its more obvious relatives.)\n\nAlas, the new strain wasn't as innocuous as it seemed. Patients had one thing in common: a weakened immune system.\n\nThere's not much doctors can do to help them. For transplant patients, one option is lowering the doses of immunosuppressive drugs to allow the immune system to regenerate, but this increases the risk of organ rejection. Doctors also use ribavirin, a drug approved for hepatitis C and several other viral infections. But there hasn't been a controlled trial yet, and ribavirin has serious side effects.\n\nThese patients are the visible part of a much wider epidemic. Surveys have shown that 17% of adults in Germany have antibodies against the virus, meaning they became infected at some point; so do 14% in Austria, 4% in southern Italy, and 27% in the Netherlands. One Dutch study found that antibody levels in people aged 18 to 21 dropped from almost 20% in 1995 to less than 5% in 2000, then rose again to 13% in 2011, which suggests the infection is re-emerging, says Zaaijer, a co-author on the study.\n\nBlood and blood products account for at least some of the new infections. One study suggested that 1200 blood components containing the virus are transfused each year in the United Kingdom, and roughly one in 1000 blood donors in the Netherlands carries the virus. (By contrast, a recent U.S. study found the virus's genetic material in just one donor per 9500.)\n\nA much bigger risk factor is the consumption of sausages and other pork products. Hepatitis E has been shown to be ubiquitous in swine herds in many European countries. Most animals become infected without getting sick between 3 and 6 months after birth, when antibodies inherited from their mothers start to wane. And there's strong evidence that the virus is passed on to humans through pork. In one study, Wim van der Poel, a veterinary virologist at Wageningen University and Research Centre in the Netherlands, analyzed hepatitis E sequences found in Dutch blood donors between 2010 and 2015. \"When we looked for the closest sequence ever found, [it] was always a swine sequence from the same region,\" he says.\n\nWhat's unclear is which pork products carry the highest risk. In one region in the south of France, infections have been linked to consumption of figatellu, a pig liver sausage that's often eaten raw. Scientists are still trying to pinpoint which other products contain the virus. It's difficult to culture the virus from meat products, and looking directly for viral RNA is technically complicated; moreover, finding RNA does not mean the food contains intact virus that can infect a consumer. Meanwhile, some studies have also shown a risk from eating shellfish or fruit.\n\nIn the United States, in contrast, hepatitis E \"is very rare even in transplant patients and the immunosuppressed,\" says Jay Hoofnagle of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases in Bethesda, Maryland. One theory is that U.S. residents eat less raw or undercooked pork. Another theory: Pigs in Europe may suffer from immune deficiencies because of some other infection. \"An HIV-like agent may cause pigs or wild boar to develop chronic HEV infection,\" Hoofnagle says.\n\nWith so many unknowns, controlling this silent epidemic is a challenge. Ireland already screens blood products for hepatitis E, and other countries are debating doing so. Like everything else involving the blood supply, \"it's a touchy subject,\" Pischke says. Screening is costly and may not make sense for the general population, which has little to fear from HEV, says Rainer Seitz, head of transfusion medicine at the Paul Ehrlich Institute in Langen, Germany, a federal institute responsible for blood safety. But he supports screening blood products before use in immunocompromised patients. The virus's apparent ubiquity in pork products and elsewhere in the environment also makes general blood screening questionable, Zaaijer says. \"It's like screening donors for flu in times of flu. The blood is safe, but the air isn't,\" he says. It's far more important to make food and water free of hepatitis E, he adds.\n\nOne way to do that would be to vaccinate pigs. A human vaccine has already been approved in China, and scientists think a swine vaccine is feasible as well. But getting pig farmers to adopt it would be difficult, Van der Poel predicts, because their animals don't get sick. UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4445881", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - Europe: zoonotic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4445881", "date": "2016-08-28 19:03:33", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - EUROPE: ZOONOTIC\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Aug 2016\nSource: Science Vol. 353, Issue 6302, pp. 862-863 [edited]\nhttp://science.sciencemag.org/content/353/6302/862.full\n\n\nAlmost immediately after a man received a new heart, his body began to reject it. France: (VR) raw pork liver sausage 20141010.2850748\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jammu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bethesda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amsterdam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4405317", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Sudan: (ND) IDP camp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4405317", "date": "2016-02-21 17:27:14", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - INDIA (03): (HIMACHAL PRADESH) FATAL\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 Feb 2016\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/N5P3AN\n\n\nIn perhaps the worst tragedy related to jaundice deaths in the town, a young lawyer lost his 25 year old wife 4 days after the birth of a baby girl, born at the state's Kamla Nehru hospital on 13 Feb 2016. The woman, married only a year before, was admitted to the hospital last week where she delivered a healthy baby girl, but 2 days later, she was found to be jaundiced.\n\n\"She was immediately moved to Indira Gandhi Medical Collage (IGMC) Shimla where she was kept in the intensive care unit hoping for her improvement. For 2 days, she remained in the ICU, but she fell victim to the disease,\" confirmed one of her husband's colleagues.\n\nThe number of deaths due to jaundice has risen to 10, which is still being disputed by the medical authorities, who have put the number at 4.\n\n[byline: Ashwani Sharma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous posting about the outbreak centered in Shimla in Himachal Pradesh identified the cause as hepatitis E. Hepatitis E virus (HEV), which is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, is the commonest cause of acute viral hepatitis globally. Large HEV outbreaks have been documented in crowded settings that have poor water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions. Pregnant women suffer disproportionately high mortality from hepatitis E.\n\nA newly published paper provides some important potential insight into why there is a substantially increased maternal mortality rate related to hepatitis E virus:\n\nKmush BL, Labrique A, Li W, et al. The association of cytokines and micronutrients with hepatitis E virus infection during pregnancy and the postpartum period in rural Bangladesh. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2016;94: 203-11; http://dx.doi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0238.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is severe during pregnancy, with a pregnant case fatality rate around 30 per cent. In Bangladesh, plasma samples from 1100 women during the 1st trimester (TM) and 3rd TM of pregnancy and 3 months postpartum (PP) were tested for anti-HEV IgG. During this time, 40 women developed antibody responses to HEV. These seroconverters are classified as the cases (incidence = 46 infections per 1000 person-years). All except 1 seroconversion occurred between the 3rd TM and 3 months PP. The cases and 40 matched non-seroconverters (controls) underwent analysis of a panel of 10 cytokines, 12 vitamins and minerals, and 2 markers of inflammation. Throughout pregnancy, seroconverting cases displayed higher concentrations of both pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines compared with the non-seroconverting controls, even prior to infection. In the 1st TM, seroconverters had lower circulating zinc concentrations (P = 0.03), an increased prevalence of vitamin D deficiency (25-hydroxy vitamin D [25(OH)2D] less than 50 nmol/L, P = 0.08), and anemia (hemoglobin less than 110 g/L, P = 0.05) compared with controls. There were no differences in C-reactive protein or alpha-1-acid glycoprotein. Antecedent micronutrient deficiencies may lead to dysregulated cytokine expression and immunologic compromise, increasing the risk of HEV infection, especially during pregnancy. This exploratory analysis reveals potential novel associations that deserve further study.\"\n\nA recombinant, 3-dose series HEV vaccine has been produced but has not yet been pre-qualified by WHO. The vaccine has been shown to prevent symptomatic HEV infection and proven to be safe and effective in people aged 16-64 years. Limited vaccine safety data in 37 pregnant women receiving 57 doses have been reported; however, further research is needed, and safety for children is unknown. The vaccine is expected to be protective against HEV genotype 1, the strain associated with most waterborne outbreaks in Africa and Asia.\n\nHimachal Pradesh (literally \"snow-laden region\") is a state in North India, forming part of the larger Punjab region, and can be found on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh#/media/File:India_Himachal_Pradesh_locator_map.svg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304.]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - India (02): (HP) fatalities 20160212.4016257\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh: pregnancy, increased mortality, risk factors 20160115.3938772\nHepatitis E - India: (HP) waterborne, susp 20160108.3921128\n2015\n---\nHepatitis E - France: 2013, raw pork stuffing 20151021.3733016\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked imported pork sausage, 2014 20150908.3631747\nHepatitis E - Spain: HIV infected individuals 20150314.3230174\nHepatitis E - Philippines: (TR) human, swine 20150209.3152769\n2014\n---\nHepatitis - India (03): (HP) hepatitis E susp 20141224.3051859\nHepatitis E - Ethiopia: (GA) refugees 20140810.2676571\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\nHepatitis E - Nepal (02): (MO) 20140515.247\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-02-13 00:00:00", "1100-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shimla", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4126018", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis A - For 2 days, she remained in the ICU, but she fell victim to the disease,\" confirmed one of her husband's colleagues.\n\nThe number of deaths due to jaundice has risen to 10, which is still being disputed by the medical authorities, who have put the number at 4.\n\n[byline: Ashwani Sharma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous posting about the outbreak centered in Shimla in Himachal Pradesh identified the cause as hepatitis E. Ethiopia: (GA) refugees 20140810.2676571\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\nHepatitis E - Nepal (02): (MO) 20140515.247\n.................................................sb/ll/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-02-13 00:00:00", "1100-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shimla", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4060023", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - India (06): (JK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4060023", "date": "2016-02-21 17:27:14", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - INDIA (03): (HIMACHAL PRADESH) FATAL\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 Feb 2016\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://goo.gl/N5P3AN\n\n\nIn perhaps the worst tragedy related to jaundice deaths in the town, a young lawyer lost his 25 year old wife 4 days after the birth of a baby girl, born at the state's Kamla Nehru hospital on 13 Feb 2016. The woman, married only a year before, was admitted to the hospital last week where she delivered a healthy baby girl, but 2 days later, she was found to be jaundiced.\n\n\"She was immediately moved to Indira Gandhi Medical Collage (IGMC) Shimla where she was kept in the intensive care unit hoping for her improvement. For 2 days, she remained in the ICU, but she fell victim to the disease,\" confirmed one of her husband's colleagues.\n\nThe number of deaths due to jaundice has risen to 10, which is still being disputed by the medical authorities, who have put the number at 4.\n\n[byline: Ashwani Sharma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous posting about the outbreak centered in Shimla in Himachal Pradesh identified the cause as hepatitis E. Hepatitis E virus (HEV), which is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, is the commonest cause of acute viral hepatitis globally. Large HEV outbreaks have been documented in crowded settings that have poor water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions. Pregnant women suffer disproportionately high mortality from hepatitis E.\n\nA newly published paper provides some important potential insight into why there is a substantially increased maternal mortality rate related to hepatitis E virus:\n\nKmush BL, Labrique A, Li W, et al. The association of cytokines and micronutrients with hepatitis E virus infection during pregnancy and the postpartum period in rural Bangladesh. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2016;94: 203-11; http://dx.doi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0238.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n\"Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is severe during pregnancy, with a pregnant case fatality rate around 30 per cent. In Bangladesh, plasma samples from 1100 women during the 1st trimester (TM) and 3rd TM of pregnancy and 3 months postpartum (PP) were tested for anti-HEV IgG. During this time, 40 women developed antibody responses to HEV. These seroconverters are classified as the cases (incidence = 46 infections per 1000 person-years). All except 1 seroconversion occurred between the 3rd TM and 3 months PP. The cases and 40 matched non-seroconverters (controls) underwent analysis of a panel of 10 cytokines, 12 vitamins and minerals, and 2 markers of inflammation. Throughout pregnancy, seroconverting cases displayed higher concentrations of both pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines compared with the non-seroconverting controls, even prior to infection. In the 1st TM, seroconverters had lower circulating zinc concentrations (P = 0.03), an increased prevalence of vitamin D deficiency (25-hydroxy vitamin D [25(OH)2D] less than 50 nmol/L, P = 0.08), and anemia (hemoglobin less than 110 g/L, P = 0.05) compared with controls. There were no differences in C-reactive protein or alpha-1-acid glycoprotein. Antecedent micronutrient deficiencies may lead to dysregulated cytokine expression and immunologic compromise, increasing the risk of HEV infection, especially during pregnancy. This exploratory analysis reveals potential novel associations that deserve further study.\"\n\nA recombinant, 3-dose series HEV vaccine has been produced but has not yet been pre-qualified by WHO. The vaccine has been shown to prevent symptomatic HEV infection and proven to be safe and effective in people aged 16-64 years. Limited vaccine safety data in 37 pregnant women receiving 57 doses have been reported; however, further research is needed, and safety for children is unknown. The vaccine is expected to be protective against HEV genotype 1, the strain associated with most waterborne outbreaks in Africa and Asia.\n\nHimachal Pradesh (literally \"snow-laden region\") is a state in North India, forming part of the larger Punjab region, and can be found on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh#/media/File:India_Himachal_Pradesh_locator_map.svg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304.]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - India (02): (HP) fatalities 20160212.4016257\nHepatitis E - Bangladesh: pregnancy, increased mortality, risk factors 20160115.3938772\nHepatitis E - India: (HP) waterborne, susp 20160108.3921128\n2015\n---\nHepatitis E - France: 2013, raw pork stuffing 20151021.3733016\nHepatitis E - UK: undercooked imported pork sausage, 2014 20150908.3631747\nHepatitis E - Spain: HIV infected individuals 20150314.3230174\nHepatitis E - Philippines: (TR) human, swine 20150209.3152769\n2014\n---\nHepatitis - India (03): (HP) hepatitis E susp 20141224.3051859\nHepatitis E - For 2 days, she remained in the ICU, but she fell victim to the disease,\" confirmed one of her husband's colleagues.\n\nThe number of deaths due to jaundice has risen to 10, which is still being disputed by the medical authorities, who have put the number at 4.\n\n[byline: Ashwani Sharma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous posting about the outbreak centered in Shimla in Himachal Pradesh identified the cause as hepatitis E. For 2 days, she remained in the ICU, but she fell victim to the disease,\" confirmed one of her husband's colleagues.\n\nThe number of deaths due to jaundice has risen to 10, which is still being disputed by the medical authorities, who have put the number at 4.\n\n[byline: Ashwani Sharma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous posting about the outbreak centered in Shimla in Himachal Pradesh identified the cause as hepatitis E. This exploratory analysis reveals potential novel associations that deserve further study.\"\n\nA recombinant, 3-dose series HEV vaccine has been produced but has not yet been pre-qualified by WHO. The vaccine has been shown to prevent symptomatic HEV infection and proven to be safe and effective in people aged 16-64 years. Limited vaccine safety data in 37 pregnant women receiving 57 doses have been reported; however, further research is needed, and safety for children is unknown. India (02): (HP) fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4016257", "date": "2015-05-17 18:32:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, PET RABBIT - ITALY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: June 2015\nSource: Transboundary and Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tbed.12348/abstract\n\n\nHepatitis E Virus: First Description in a Pet House Rabbit. A New Transmission Route for Human? Authors: C. Caruso, P. Modesto, R. Prato, F. E. Scaglione, L. De Marco, E. Bollo, P. L. Acutis, L. Masoero and S. Peletto\n------------------------------------------\nSummary:\nIn this work, we identified for the 1st time hepatitis E virus (HEV) in a pet house rabbit, an adult 7-year-old female domestic rabbit (_Oryctolagus cuniculus_). Importantly, the resulting phylogenetic tree showed that the HEV strain identified in the pet house rabbit was closely related to a human HEV sequence; this finding reawakens concerns regarding the zoonotic risk represented by HEV in animals and adds house rabbits to the spectrum of potential sources of infection for humans. Potential for domestic transmission of HEV to humans should be taken into account.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To access the article, go to http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tbed.12348/abstract.\n\nStrains of hepatitis E virus (HEV) were found in rabbits (wild and farmed) in USA, Mongolia and France. Other reports showed that other mammals such as pigs, deer, rats, mongooses, ferrets, chickens, and trout also may harbor strains of HEV. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The rabbit died suddenly. It had been regularly vaccinated against rabbit hemorrhasgic disease & myxomatosis. - Mod.JW\n\nHealthMaps of the affected areas can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awJX and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands (02): biosecurity 20120810.1237757\n2011\n----\nHepatitis E, lagomorphs - USA 20111129.3479\n.................................................pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3938772", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Bangladesh: pregnancy, increased mortality, risk factors", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3938772", "date": "2015-05-17 18:32:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, PET RABBIT - ITALY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: June 2015\nSource: Transboundary and Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tbed.12348/abstract\n\n\nHepatitis E Virus: First Description in a Pet House Rabbit.
