A New Transmission Route for Human? Authors: C. Caruso, P. Modesto, R. Prato, F. E. Scaglione, L. De Marco, E. Bollo, P. L. Acutis, L. Masoero and S. Peletto\n------------------------------------------\nSummary:\nIn this work, we identified for the 1st time hepatitis E virus (HEV) in a pet house rabbit, an adult 7-year-old female domestic rabbit (_Oryctolagus cuniculus_). Importantly, the resulting phylogenetic tree showed that the HEV strain identified in the pet house rabbit was closely related to a human HEV sequence; this finding reawakens concerns regarding the zoonotic risk represented by HEV in animals and adds house rabbits to the spectrum of potential sources of infection for humans. Potential for domestic transmission of HEV to humans should be taken into account.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To access the article, go to http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tbed.12348/abstract.\n\nStrains of hepatitis E virus (HEV) were found in rabbits (wild and farmed) in USA, Mongolia and France. Other reports showed that other mammals such as pigs, deer, rats, mongooses, ferrets, chickens, and trout also may harbor strains of HEV. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The rabbit died suddenly. It had been regularly vaccinated against rabbit hemorrhasgic disease & myxomatosis. - Mod.JW\n\nHealthMaps of the affected areas can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awJX and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands (02): biosecurity 20120810.1237757\n2011\n----\nHepatitis E, lagomorphs - USA 20111129.3479\n.................................................pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3292842", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Nepal (02): ex India, commentary", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3292842", "date": "2014-10-10 13:59:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (VAR) RAW PORK LIVER SAUSAGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2014\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/11/14-0791_article\n\n\nRef: Renou C, Roque Afonso AM, Pavio N: Foodborne transmission of hepatitis E virus from raw pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. The HEV genotype was 3f, as determined from the phylogenetic analysis of a portion of the open reading frame (ORF) 2 (2). The index case-patient recovered by the end of January 2014. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. The patient had most recently eaten figatelli at a lunch with 8 family members on 28 Oct 2013, 7 weeks before illness onset. After receiving informed consent, we conducted laboratory investigations of samples from the other family members; tests included HEV serology and HEV RNA detection in serum and fecal samples. Samples were obtained from family members during January 8-21 Jan 2014 (41-54 days after the lunch). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2. Haim-Boukobza S, Ferey MP, Vetillard AL, et al: Transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E in a misleading context of autoimmunity and drug-induced toxicity. J Hepatol. 2012; 57(6): 1374-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2012.08.001 [available at http://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(12)00621-6/pdf].\n3. Barnaud E, Rogee S, Garry P, et al: Thermal inactivation of infectious hepatitis E virus in experimentally contaminated food. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2012; 78(15): 5153-9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3416424/].\n4. Li TC, Chijiwa K, Sera N, et al: Hepatitis E virus transmission from wild boar meat. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005; 11(12): 1958-60 9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3367655/].\n5. Tei S, Kitajima N, Takahashi K, Mishiro S: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from deer to human beings. Lancet. 2003; 362(9381): 371-3 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12907011].\n6. Riveiro-Barciela M, Minguez B, Girones R, et al: Phylogenetic demonstration of hepatitis E infection transmitted by pork meat ingestion. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2014; (in press) [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24637729].\n7. Pavio N, Meng XJ, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/].\n8. Colson P, Borentain P, Queyriaux B, et al: Pig liver sausage as a source of hepatitis E virus transmission to humans. J Infect Dis. 2010; 202(6): 825-34 [available at http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/202/6/825.long].\n9. Berto A, Grierson S, Hakze-van der Honing R, et al: Hepatitis E virus in pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(2): 264-6 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3563277/].\n10. Ministere du Travail, de l'Emploi et de la Sante. Prevenir l'hepatite E chez les personnes susceptibles de developper une forme grave [cited 2014 Sep 17]; http://www.sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Fiche_Hepatite_E.pdf [in French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is in part derived from Pavio N, Meng X-J, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46. doi: 10.1051/vetres/2010018 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/):\n\nThe particularity of HEV is that, among all known major hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, and D), HEV is the only one with certain genotypes (3 and 4) with animal reservoirs. Swine HEV was first isolated and genetically characterized from pigs in the USA in 1997, even though HEV antibodies and RNA were reportedly detected from pigs in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal but the identity of the virus infecting the Nepalese pigs was not determined in that study. More recently, an avian HEV was identified and characterized from chickens with Hepatitis-Splenomegaly (HS) syndrome in 2001 in the USA as well. Besides swine and chickens, recently strains of HEV have been genetically identified from deer, mongooses, rabbits, and rats.\n\nAccumulating evidence indicates that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and swine (and likely other animal species) are reservoirs. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Thus, zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E raises an important public health concern over food safety and zoonotic risk. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34866. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1265-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-01-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1374-08-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "5153-09-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hyeres", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Vet Res", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borentain P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tei S", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Erdre", "country": "France"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marseille", "country": "France"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Hepatol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3287964", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Nepal: ex India", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3287964", "date": "2014-10-10 13:59:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (VAR) RAW PORK LIVER SAUSAGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2014\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/11/14-0791_article\n\n\nRef: Renou C, Roque Afonso AM, Pavio N: Foodborne transmission of hepatitis E virus from raw pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. The HEV genotype was 3f, as determined from the phylogenetic analysis of a portion of the open reading frame (ORF) 2 (2). The index case-patient recovered by the end of January 2014. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. The patient had most recently eaten figatelli at a lunch with 8 family members on 28 Oct 2013, 7 weeks before illness onset. After receiving informed consent, we conducted laboratory investigations of samples from the other family members; tests included HEV serology and HEV RNA detection in serum and fecal samples. Samples were obtained from family members during January 8-21 Jan 2014 (41-54 days after the lunch). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2. Haim-Boukobza S, Ferey MP, Vetillard AL, et al: Transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E in a misleading context of autoimmunity and drug-induced toxicity. J Hepatol. 2012; 57(6): 1374-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2012.08.001 [available at http://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(12)00621-6/pdf].\n3. Barnaud E, Rogee S, Garry P, et al: Thermal inactivation of infectious hepatitis E virus in experimentally contaminated food. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2012; 78(15): 5153-9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3416424/].\n4. Li TC, Chijiwa K, Sera N, et al: Hepatitis E virus transmission from wild boar meat. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005; 11(12): 1958-60 9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3367655/].\n5. Tei S, Kitajima N, Takahashi K, Mishiro S: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from deer to human beings. Lancet. 2003; 362(9381): 371-3 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12907011].\n6. Riveiro-Barciela M, Minguez B, Girones R, et al: Phylogenetic demonstration of hepatitis E infection transmitted by pork meat ingestion. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2014; (in press) [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24637729].\n7. Pavio N, Meng XJ, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/].\n8. Colson P, Borentain P, Queyriaux B, et al: Pig liver sausage as a source of hepatitis E virus transmission to humans. J Infect Dis. 2010; 202(6): 825-34 [available at http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/202/6/825.long].\n9. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(2): 264-6 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3563277/].\n10. Ministere du Travail, de l'Emploi et de la Sante. Prevenir l'hepatite E chez les personnes susceptibles de developper une forme grave [cited 2014 Sep 17]; http://www.sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Fiche_Hepatite_E.pdf [in French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is in part derived from Pavio N, Meng X-J, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46. doi: 10.1051/vetres/2010018 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/):\n\nThe particularity of HEV is that, among all known major hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, and D), HEV is the only one with certain genotypes (3 and 4) with animal reservoirs. Swine HEV was first isolated and genetically characterized from pigs in the USA in 1997, even though HEV antibodies and RNA were reportedly detected from pigs in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal but the identity of the virus infecting the Nepalese pigs was not determined in that study. More recently, an avian HEV was identified and characterized from chickens with Hepatitis-Splenomegaly (HS) syndrome in 2001 in the USA as well. Besides swine and chickens, recently strains of HEV have been genetically identified from deer, mongooses, rabbits, and rats.\n\nAccumulating evidence indicates that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and swine (and likely other animal species) are reservoirs. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Thus, zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E raises an important public health concern over food safety and zoonotic risk. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34866. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1265-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-01-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1374-08-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "5153-09-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hyeres", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Vet Res", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borentain P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tei S", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Erdre", "country": "France"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marseille", "country": "France"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Hepatol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3051859", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis - India (03): (HP) hepatitis E susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3051859", "date": "2014-10-10 13:59:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (VAR) RAW PORK LIVER SAUSAGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2014\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/11/14-0791_article\n\n\nRef: Renou C, Roque Afonso AM, Pavio N: Foodborne transmission of hepatitis E virus from raw pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. The HEV genotype was 3f, as determined from the phylogenetic analysis of a portion of the open reading frame (ORF) 2 (2). The index case-patient recovered by the end of January 2014. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. The patient had most recently eaten figatelli at a lunch with 8 family members on 28 Oct 2013, 7 weeks before illness onset. After receiving informed consent, we conducted laboratory investigations of samples from the other family members; tests included HEV serology and HEV RNA detection in serum and fecal samples. Samples were obtained from family members during January 8-21 Jan 2014 (41-54 days after the lunch). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2. Haim-Boukobza S, Ferey MP, Vetillard AL, et al: Transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E in a misleading context of autoimmunity and drug-induced toxicity. J Hepatol. 2012; 57(6): 1374-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2012.08.001 [available at http://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(12)00621-6/pdf].\n3. Barnaud E, Rogee S, Garry P, et al: Thermal inactivation of infectious hepatitis E virus in experimentally contaminated food. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2012; 78(15): 5153-9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3416424/].\n4. Li TC, Chijiwa K, Sera N, et al: Hepatitis E virus transmission from wild boar meat. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005; 11(12): 1958-60 9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3367655/].\n5. Tei S, Kitajima N, Takahashi K, Mishiro S: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from deer to human beings. Lancet. 2003; 362(9381): 371-3 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12907011].\n6. Riveiro-Barciela M, Minguez B, Girones R, et al: Phylogenetic demonstration of hepatitis E infection transmitted by pork meat ingestion. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2014; (in press) [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24637729].\n7. Pavio N, Meng XJ, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/].\n8. Colson P, Borentain P, Queyriaux B, et al: Pig liver sausage as a source of hepatitis E virus transmission to humans. J Infect Dis. 2010; 202(6): 825-34 [available at http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/202/6/825.long].\n9. Berto A, Grierson S, Hakze-van der Honing R, et al: Hepatitis E virus in pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(2): 264-6 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3563277/].\n10. Ministere du Travail, de l'Emploi et de la Sante. Prevenir l'hepatite E chez les personnes susceptibles de developper une forme grave [cited 2014 Sep 17]; http://www.sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Fiche_Hepatite_E.pdf [in French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is in part derived from Pavio N, Meng X-J, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46. doi: 10.1051/vetres/2010018 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/):\n\nThe particularity of HEV is that, among all known major hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, and D), HEV is the only one with certain genotypes (3 and 4) with animal reservoirs. Swine HEV was first isolated and genetically characterized from pigs in the USA in 1997, even though HEV antibodies and RNA were reportedly detected from pigs in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal but the identity of the virus infecting the Nepalese pigs was not determined in that study. More recently, an avian HEV was identified and characterized from chickens with Hepatitis-Splenomegaly (HS) syndrome in 2001 in the USA as well. Besides swine and chickens, recently strains of HEV have been genetically identified from deer, mongooses, rabbits, and rats.\n\nAccumulating evidence indicates that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and swine (and likely other animal species) are reservoirs. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Thus, zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E raises an important public health concern over food safety and zoonotic risk. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34866. - Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2. Haim-Boukobza S, Ferey MP, Vetillard AL, et al: Transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E in a misleading context of autoimmunity and drug-induced toxicity. J Hepatol. 2012; 57(6): 1374-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2012.08.001 [available at http://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(12)00621-6/pdf].\n3. Barnaud E, Rogee S, Garry P, et al: Thermal inactivation of infectious hepatitis E virus in experimentally contaminated food. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2012; 78(15): 5153-9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3416424/].\n4. Li TC, Chijiwa K, Sera N, et al: Hepatitis E virus transmission from wild boar meat. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005; 11(12): 1958-60 9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3367655/].\n5. Tei S, Kitajima N, Takahashi K, Mishiro S: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from deer to human beings. Lancet. 2003; 362(9381): 371-3 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12907011].\n6. Riveiro-Barciela M, Minguez B, Girones R, et al: Phylogenetic demonstration of hepatitis E infection transmitted by pork meat ingestion. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2014; (in press) [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24637729].\n7. Pavio N, Meng XJ, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/].\n8. Colson P, Borentain P, Queyriaux B, et al: Pig liver sausage as a source of hepatitis E virus transmission to humans. J Infect Dis. 2010; 202(6): 825-34 [available at http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/202/6/825.long].\n9. Berto A, Grierson S, Hakze-van der Honing R, et al: Hepatitis E virus in pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(2): 264-6 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3563277/].\n10. Ministere du Travail, de l'Emploi et de la Sante. Prevenir l'hepatite E chez les personnes susceptibles de developper une forme grave [cited 2014 Sep 17]; http://www.sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Fiche_Hepatite_E.pdf [in French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is in part derived from Pavio N, Meng X-J, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46. doi: 10.1051/vetres/2010018 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/):\n\nThe particularity of HEV is that, among all known major hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, and D), HEV is the only one with certain genotypes (3 and 4) with animal reservoirs. Swine HEV was first isolated and genetically characterized from pigs in the USA in 1997, even though HEV antibodies and RNA were reportedly detected from pigs in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal but the identity of the virus infecting the Nepalese pigs was not determined in that study. More recently, an avian HEV was identified and characterized from chickens with Hepatitis-Splenomegaly (HS) syndrome in 2001 in the USA as well. Besides swine and chickens, recently strains of HEV have been genetically identified from deer, mongooses, rabbits, and rats.\n\nAccumulating evidence indicates that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and swine (and likely other animal species) are reservoirs. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Thus, zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E raises an important public health concern over food safety and zoonotic risk. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34866. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1265-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-01-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1374-08-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "5153-09-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hyeres", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Vet Res", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borentain P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tei S", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Erdre", "country": "France"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marseille", "country": "France"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Hepatol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2921487", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis - India: (OR) hepatitis E, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2921487", "date": "2014-10-10 13:59:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (VAR) RAW PORK LIVER SAUSAGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2014\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/11/14-0791_article\n\n\nRef: Renou C, Roque Afonso AM, Pavio N: Foodborne transmission of hepatitis E virus from raw pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. The HEV genotype was 3f, as determined from the phylogenetic analysis of a portion of the open reading frame (ORF) 2 (2). The index case-patient recovered by the end of January 2014. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. The patient had most recently eaten figatelli at a lunch with 8 family members on 28 Oct 2013, 7 weeks before illness onset. After receiving informed consent, we conducted laboratory investigations of samples from the other family members; tests included HEV serology and HEV RNA detection in serum and fecal samples. Samples were obtained from family members during January 8-21 Jan 2014 (41-54 days after the lunch). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2. Haim-Boukobza S, Ferey MP, Vetillard AL, et al: Transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E in a misleading context of autoimmunity and drug-induced toxicity. J Hepatol. 2012; 57(6): 1374-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2012.08.001 [available at http://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(12)00621-6/pdf].\n3. Barnaud E, Rogee S, Garry P, et al: Thermal inactivation of infectious hepatitis E virus in experimentally contaminated food. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2012; 78(15): 5153-9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3416424/].\n4. Li TC, Chijiwa K, Sera N, et al: Hepatitis E virus transmission from wild boar meat. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005; 11(12): 1958-60 9 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3367655/].\n5. Tei S, Kitajima N, Takahashi K, Mishiro S: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from deer to human beings. Lancet. 2003; 362(9381): 371-3 [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12907011].\n6. Riveiro-Barciela M, Minguez B, Girones R, et al: Phylogenetic demonstration of hepatitis E infection transmitted by pork meat ingestion. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2014; (in press) [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24637729].\n7. Pavio N, Meng XJ, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46 [available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/].\n8. Prevenir l'hepatite E chez les personnes susceptibles de developper une forme grave [cited 2014 Sep 17]; http://www.sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/Fiche_Hepatite_E.pdf [in French]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is in part derived from Pavio N, Meng X-J, Renou C: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks. Vet Res. 2010; 41(6): 46. doi: 10.1051/vetres/2010018 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2865210/):\n\nThe particularity of HEV is that, among all known major hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, and D), HEV is the only one with certain genotypes (3 and 4) with animal reservoirs. Swine HEV was first isolated and genetically characterized from pigs in the USA in 1997, even though HEV antibodies and RNA were reportedly detected from pigs in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal but the identity of the virus infecting the Nepalese pigs was not determined in that study. More recently, an avian HEV was identified and characterized from chickens with Hepatitis-Splenomegaly (HS) syndrome in 2001 in the USA as well. Besides swine and chickens, recently strains of HEV have been genetically identified from deer, mongooses, rabbits, and rats.\n\nAccumulating evidence indicates that hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and swine (and likely other animal species) are reservoirs. Swine and human strains of HEV are genetically closely related and, in some cases, indistinguishable, and direct transmissions through the consumption of contaminated food products such as pork have been reported in Japan. Thus, zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E raises an important public health concern over food safety and zoonotic risk. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34866. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Australia: (NSW), undercooked pork liver 20140914.2773538\nHepatitis E - Germany: genotype 3, transfusion related 20140529.2506353\n2013\n----\nHepatitis E - UK: pork sausages, alert 20130915.1946331\n.................................................ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1265-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-01-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1374-08-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "5153-09-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-17 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hyeres", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Vet Res", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Borentain P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tei S", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Erdre", "country": "France"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marseille", "country": "France"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Hepatol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2850748", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - France: (VR) raw pork liver sausage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2850748", "date": "2014-10-10 13:59:16", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (VAR) RAW PORK LIVER SAUSAGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2014\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/11/14-0791_article\n\n\nRef: Renou C, Roque Afonso AM, Pavio N: Foodborne transmission of hepatitis E virus from raw pork liver sausage, France. Emerg Infect Dis 2014; 20(11) [date cited]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of sporadic autochthonous cases of acute hepatitis E is increasing in many industrialized countries (1). These cases involve hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes 3 and 4, which are zoonotic. Although risk for foodborne transmission from pork is now recognized, we report here direct HEV transmission through ingestion of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu [plural: figatelli]) in southeastern France.\n\nThe index case-patient was a 45-year-old woman from Hyeres ([a commune in the Var department in the Provence-Alpes-C\u00f4te d'Azur regionin] southeastern France) who had no underlying medical condition. She visited her general practitioner on 17 Dec 2013, reporting 3 days of weakness. Acute hepatitis was diagnosed 2 days later on the basis of elevated liver enzymes (alanine aminotransferase 1265 IU/L [reference less than 35 IU/L]) and bilirubin (65 micromol/L [reference less than 17 micromol/L]). Serum markers for acute hepatitis A, B, and C; cytomegalovirus; and Epstein-Barr virus were negative. Jaundice appeared on 19 Dec 2013 and the patient was referred to the Medical Unit of Hyeres for additional investigations. A serum sample collected on 20 Dec 2013 tested positive for HEV RNA; viral load was 3.3 log10 IU/mL (Ceeram, La Chapelle sur Erdre, France), and IgM and IgG against HEV were found (Wantai, Beijing, China), which led to the diagnosis of acute hepatitis E. The HEV genotype was 3f, as determined from the phylogenetic analysis of a portion of the open reading frame (ORF) 2 (2). The index case-patient recovered by the end of January 2014. HEV viremia was undetectable on 17 Jan 2014.\n\nThe index case-patient and her family regularly ate figatelli (raw pork liver sausages) made in Corsica. The patient had most recently eaten figatelli at a lunch with 8 family members on 28 Oct 2013, 7 weeks before illness onset. After receiving informed consent, we conducted laboratory investigations of samples from the other family members; tests included HEV serology and HEV RNA detection in serum and fecal samples. Samples were obtained from family members during January 8-21 Jan 2014 (41-54 days after the lunch). Positive HEV IgM and detectable HEV RNA were found in the serum of the index case-patient's daughter, who was asymptomatic. Because the sample was tested 10 weeks after the family lunch, the daughter's HEV viral load was too low to enable sequence characterization and clustering of HEV strains. 3 other family members were IgG positive for HEV, indicating previous HEV infection. Leftover sausages had been kept frozen and were available for HEV testing.\n\nHEV RNA was detectable from the leftover sausages, and HEV sequences were amplified in 2 different genomic regions (ORF1: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and ORF2), as described previously (2). Comparison with the index case-patient's sequences showed 100 percent identity for both regions (Figure - for figure, see source URL above - Mod.LL). Samples of food and samples from the index case-patient were analyzed in 2 independent laboratories to avoid any cross-contamination. The level of contamination of the figatellu was 48 000 copies of HEV RNA/g of sausage (3).\n\nFigatellu, a dried sausage, contains 30 percent pork liver and no heating step occurs during its manufacture. Usually deep cooking is recommended on the package, but consumers might not follow the cooking recommendation; also, figatelli can be sold in small local shops with no label. In the instance reported here, the figatellu was sold without any warning label and was eaten raw.\n\nThat HEV was transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food is supported by the following evidence:\n- 3 case reports have provided direct evidence of HEV transmission through ingestion of contaminated animal food products with identical or near identical sequences between the patients and the contaminated food they ate. 2 cases occurred in the early 2000s in Japan through consumption of grilled wild boar (4) or sashimi of Sika deer (5); the 3rd, reported recently in Spain, was transmitted through ingestion of pig meat (6).\n- HEV widely infects domestic pigs and wild boar (7).\n- Swine and human HEV strains have genetic similarities and, in some cases, are indistinguishable (1).\n- In Marseille, France, a case-control study identified ingestion of figatellu as a risk factor for HEV infection. Genetic similarities were found between sequences isolated from patients with autochthonous hepatitis E and nonrelated figatelli purchased in the same region (8). Finally, infectious virus, replicating in a 3-dimensional culture system, was identified in a HEV RNA-positive figatellu (9).\n\nIn the present study, the homology between sequences recovered from the index case-patient and those recovered from leftovers of figatellu provides additional proof of HEV foodborne transmission in a Western country. In France, information about the risk for HEV transmission through the ingestion of such delicatessen was published by French authorities in 2010 (10), but the present case demonstrates that public education and warning, or larger and more explicit labels on the package, must be improved to reduce the risk for HEV exposure.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Dalton HR, Bendall R, Ijaz S, Banks M: Hepatitis E: an emerging infection in developed countries. Lancet Infect Dis. 2008; 8(11): 698-709 [abstract available at http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(08)70255-X/abstract].\n2.
