In that scenario, the current high number of viraemic and seroconverting donors may reflect a temporary elevation of HEV infection pressure. If endemic HEV infection were a recent phenomenon, the age-dependent seroprevalence could only be explained by age-dependent exposure or age-dependent susceptibility, which is difficult to imagine for a food-borne pathogen. Alternatively, the seroprevalence curve could reflect an age-cohort effect, caused by transient exposure of older generations in the past. Such a cohort effect has been described in England. The HEV incidence found in this study of 1 percent per year, as well as the high number of HEV RNA-positive blood donors, seem to contradict transient exposure to HEV in the past; but endemic HEV may have returned after a long period of absence.\n\nHEV transmission by blood transfusion has been reported in Saudi Arabia, Japan, France and the United Kingdom. Our results suggest roughly one HEV viraemic donation per day in the Netherlands. This may be an underestimation, considering that the serological screening of 5239 donors only detected antibody-positive donors in a later stage of infection, while the screening for HEV RNA of 40 176 pooled (diluted) donations detected donors in an early stage of infection, with high levels of HEV RNA and low or absent HEV antibodies. HEV RNA-positive blood may pose a threat to immunosuppressed blood recipients, such as recipients of organ transplants and patients with haematological malignancies; and possibly to pregnant women. Because blood transfusion is only a minor source of HEV infection, the routine screening of blood donations for the presence of HEV does not yet seem warranted. Each immunosuppressed patient with unexplained elevated liver enzymes should be tested for the presence of HEV RNA, irrespective of exposure to blood products. Fortunately, it appears that chronic HEV infection in immunosuppressed patients can be cured by a temporary reduction of immunosuppression, or by antiviral treatment using ribavirin.\n\nThe source and transmission routes of HEV gt-3 infection have not yet been uncovered. In contrast to the Midi-Pyrenees region of France, where an association of HEV seropositivity with rural residence was found, the level of urbanisation and the vicinity of pig farms do not play a role in the Netherlands. Until recently, little was known of HEV transmission dynamics in European pig populations. Berto et al. describe the presence of HEV in 8 to 73 percent of stool samples collected from pig farms between 2007 and 2011 throughout Europe, and the presence of HEV in fattening pigs. It is unclear whether pigs are the source of the current HEV infections. Intensive pig farming may have become the major amplifier of the virus, considering that millions of pigs are being reared in the Netherlands each year, of which each year again a large part probably acquires and sheds HEV. Subsequently, HEV may be spread via contaminated meat or via faecally contaminated water used for irrigation. Studies are needed to identify the transmission routes of HEV gt-3 to humans, so that appropriate measures can be taken. It seems likely that at this moment other Western countries also experience extensive, silent HEV infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV): a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. HEV is transmitted mainly through contaminated drinking water. It is usually a self-limiting infection and resolves within 4-6 weeks. Occasionally, a fulminant form of hepatitis develops, which can lead to death. Hepatitis E is found worldwide and different genotypes of HEV determine differences in epidemiology. Genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Although humans are considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to HEV and closely related viruses have been detected in primates and several other animal species.\n\nIn Europe, the dynamics of endemic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection remain enigmatic. The authors have studied the presence of silent HEV infection among Dutch blood donors. Genotyping of 16 of the 17 HEV RNA-positive donors revealed the presence of HEV genotype 3, which is circulating among Dutch pigs. (HEV genotypes 1 and 2 have been found only in humans, whereas genotypes 3 and 4 have also been found in animals). The authors estimate that the finding of 17 HEV RNA-positive donations among 45 415 donations corresponds to one HEV-positive blood donation per day in the Netherlands. The authors further conclude that silent HEV infection is common in the Netherlands, a situation which may apply to larger parts of Europe. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands (02): biosecurity 20120810.1237757\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands 20120807.1231416\n2011\n----\nHepatitis E - France: (SE), autochthonous & food-borne 20110412.1157\n2009\n----\nHepatitis E - France (02): background 20090918.3274\nHepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage 20090917.3267\n.................................................cp/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1401-03-16 00:00:00", "7072-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1858965", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - Netherlands: blood donors", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1858965", "date": "2013-08-01 21:09:19", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - NETHERLANDS: BLOOD DONORS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Aug 2013\nSource: Eurosurveillance Edition 2013, 18(31) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20550\n\n\nSilent hepatitis E virus infection in Dutch blood donors, 2011 to 2012\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n(By: Slot E, Hogema BM, Riezebos-Brilman A, Kok TM, Molier M, Zaaijer HL.)\n\nSummary\n-------\nIn Europe, the dynamics of endemic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection remain enigmatic. We studied the presence of silent HEV infection among Dutch blood donors. Using donations collected throughout the Netherlands in 2011 and 2012, 40 176 donations were tested for HEV RNA in 459 pools of 48 or 480 donations. Deconstruction of the reactive pools identified 13 viraemic donors. In addition, 5239 donors were tested for presence of anti-HEV IgG and IgM and for HEV RNA when IgM-positive. Of the 5239 donations, 1401 (27 percent) tested repeat-positive for HEV IgG, of which 49 (3.5 percent) also tested positive for anti-HEV IgM; 4 of the HEV IgM-positive donors tested positive for HEV RNA. HEV IgG seroprevalence ranged from 13 percent among donors younger than 30 years to 43 percent in donors older than 60 years. The finding of 17 HEV RNA-positive donations among 45 415 donations corresponds to one HEV-positive blood donation per day in the Netherlands. For 16 of the 17 HEV RNA-positive donors, genotyping succeeded, revealing HEV genotype 3, which is circulating among Dutch pigs. Apparently, silent HEV infection is common in the Netherlands, which possibly applies to larger parts of Europe.\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nHepatitis E virus (HEV) is a non-enveloped RNA virus, classified into 4 genotypes. HEV genotypes 1 and 2 have been found only in humans, whereas genotypes 3 and 4 have also been found in animals. The clinical features of hepatitis E are similar to those of viral hepatitis caused by other hepatotropic [having a special affinity for the liver] viruses. In Europe and North America, hepatitis E is known as an acute disease in travellers returning from tropical countries, but an endemic source of hepatitis E has always been suspected. Recently it became clear that genotype 3 of hepatitis E virus (HEV gt-3) is widely spread among pigs in Europe, North America and Japan. Surprisingly, infection of humans by HEV gt-3 seems to cause disease mainly in immunosuppressed persons, such as patients who have received organ transplants, who may develop chronic hepatitis E. Blood donors can be silently infected with HEV, as indicated by plasma pools testing positive for HEV RNA and by a high prevalence of antibodies to HEV among blood donors in the south west of France]. Cases of transfusion-transmitted hepatitis E have been reported. The dynamics of HEV gt-3 infection and its implications for public health and the safety of blood are largely unknown. Which part of the population has signs of resolved or active infection? To estimate the infection pressure of HEV in the Netherlands, we determined the presence of HEV RNA and HEV antibodies in a large number of recent blood donations, collected throughout the country.\n\n[Interested readers should consult the original text via the source URL to view the methodology, results, graphical presentation of the data obtained by the authors, and the references cited. - Mod.CP]\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe detection of HEV viraemia in 17 of 45 415 recent Dutch blood donations demonstrates a high incidence of HEV infection in the Netherlands. Our serological screening suggested that roughly one quarter of the Dutch adult population has experienced HEV infection. This proportion compares with the 16 percent of 500 donors in the south-west of Britain, and the 53 percent of 512 donors in the south-west of France, who recently tested positive for IgG anti-HEV, using the same antibody assay as employed in this study. Unfortunately, there is no gold standard for HEV antibody testing. A recent study reports an HEV IgG seroprevalence of only 2.6 percent in 7072 Dutch samples, collected in 2006 and 2007, employing another brand of HEV antibody assay (MP/Genelabs). The Wantai assay used in the present study may suffer from a high level of non-specific reactivity. However, studies comparing the performance of the Wantai and the MP/Genelabs assay demonstrate a higher sensitivity and detection of more sera from PCR-proven cases by the Wantai assay. Classical anti-HEV serology probably lacks sensitivity and seems unsuitable to confirm Wantai EIA test results. In addition, the frequent finding of HEV RNA-positive donors, a striking age-related increase of HEV IgG seroprevalence, and the fact that already in 2005, HEV was found to circulate on 53 of 97 Dutch pig farms, suggest that the high seroprevalence as detected by the Wantai assay may be correct.\n\nUnfortunately, seroprevalence data for persons under the age of 18 are not available. The striking age-related seroprevalence (Figure 2) is difficult to interpret. The age-dependent seroprevalence may simply reflect a long-standing, stable situation, in which people are evenly exposed to HEV in the course of their life. In that scenario, the current high number of viraemic and seroconverting donors may reflect a temporary elevation of HEV infection pressure. If endemic HEV infection were a recent phenomenon, the age-dependent seroprevalence could only be explained by age-dependent exposure or age-dependent susceptibility, which is difficult to imagine for a food-borne pathogen. Alternatively, the seroprevalence curve could reflect an age-cohort effect, caused by transient exposure of older generations in the past. Such a cohort effect has been described in England. The HEV incidence found in this study of 1 percent per year, as well as the high number of HEV RNA-positive blood donors, seem to contradict transient exposure to HEV in the past; but endemic HEV may have returned after a long period of absence.\n\nHEV transmission by blood transfusion has been reported in Saudi Arabia, Japan, France and the United Kingdom. Our results suggest roughly one HEV viraemic donation per day in the Netherlands. This may be an underestimation, considering that the serological screening of 5239 donors only detected antibody-positive donors in a later stage of infection, while the screening for HEV RNA of 40 176 pooled (diluted) donations detected donors in an early stage of infection, with high levels of HEV RNA and low or absent HEV antibodies. HEV RNA-positive blood may pose a threat to immunosuppressed blood recipients, such as recipients of organ transplants and patients with haematological malignancies; and possibly to pregnant women. Because blood transfusion is only a minor source of HEV infection, the routine screening of blood donations for the presence of HEV does not yet seem warranted. Each immunosuppressed patient with unexplained elevated liver enzymes should be tested for the presence of HEV RNA, irrespective of exposure to blood products. Fortunately, it appears that chronic HEV infection in immunosuppressed patients can be cured by a temporary reduction of immunosuppression, or by antiviral treatment using ribavirin.\n\nThe source and transmission routes of HEV gt-3 infection have not yet been uncovered. In contrast to the Midi-Pyrenees region of France, where an association of HEV seropositivity with rural residence was found, the level of urbanisation and the vicinity of pig farms do not play a role in the Netherlands. Until recently, little was known of HEV transmission dynamics in European pig populations. Berto et al. describe the presence of HEV in 8 to 73 percent of stool samples collected from pig farms between 2007 and 2011 throughout Europe, and the presence of HEV in fattening pigs. It is unclear whether pigs are the source of the current HEV infections. Intensive pig farming may have become the major amplifier of the virus, considering that millions of pigs are being reared in the Netherlands each year, of which each year again a large part probably acquires and sheds HEV. Subsequently, HEV may be spread via contaminated meat or via faecally contaminated water used for irrigation. Studies are needed to identify the transmission routes of HEV gt-3 to humans, so that appropriate measures can be taken. It seems likely that at this moment other Western countries also experience extensive, silent HEV infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV): a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. HEV is transmitted mainly through contaminated drinking water. It is usually a self-limiting infection and resolves within 4-6 weeks. Occasionally, a fulminant form of hepatitis develops, which can lead to death. Hepatitis E is found worldwide and different genotypes of HEV determine differences in epidemiology. Genotype 1 is usually seen in developing countries and causes community-level outbreaks, while genotype 3 is usually seen in the developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Although humans are considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to HEV and closely related viruses have been detected in primates and several other animal species.\n\nIn Europe, the dynamics of endemic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection remain enigmatic. The authors have studied the presence of silent HEV infection among Dutch blood donors. Genotyping of 16 of the 17 HEV RNA-positive donors revealed the presence of HEV genotype 3, which is circulating among Dutch pigs. (HEV genotypes 1 and 2 have been found only in humans, whereas genotypes 3 and 4 have also been found in animals). The authors estimate that the finding of 17 HEV RNA-positive donations among 45 415 donations corresponds to one HEV-positive blood donation per day in the Netherlands. The authors further conclude that silent HEV infection is common in the Netherlands, a situation which may apply to larger parts of Europe. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands (02): biosecurity 20120810.1237757\nHepatitis E virus, ferret - Netherlands 20120807.1231416\n2011\n----\nHepatitis E - France: (SE), autochthonous & food-borne 20110412.1157\n2009\n----\nHepatitis E - France (02): background 20090918.3274\nHepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage 20090917.3267\n.................................................cp/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1401-03-16 00:00:00", "7072-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1852456", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - India: (BR) Patna", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1852456", "date": "2013-02-03 16:56:42", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - SOUTH SUDAN: (MABAN) REFUGEE CAMPS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2013\nSource: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) [edited]\nhttp://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=6614&cat=field-news\n\n\nAn epidemic of hepatitis E is escalating across refugee camps in South Sudan's Maban county. To date, Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has treated 3991 patients in its health facilities in the camps and has recorded 88 deaths, including 15 pregnant women. Hepatitis E [virus] causes a liver disease and can lead to acute liver failure and death. It is particularly dangerous for pregnant women. Like cholera, the virus spreads in environments with poor sanitation and contaminated water. There is no cure, but its symptoms are treatable.\n\n\"We have been doing everything we can to care for people with hepatitis E [virus infection], but there is no treatment for the disease,\" says Dr. Jose-Luis Dvorzak, MSF Medical Coordinator in Maban County. \"We suspect this outbreak is far from over, and many more people will die.\"\n\nThe 1st cases appeared in June 2012. Three camps -- Jamam, then Gendrassa and Batil -- have seen the most cases so far. Numbers still have not peaked in Batil camp, where death rates have steadily risen from one or 2 per week in November [2012] to 10 per week in January [2013]. Over the past 2 weeks, MSF has identified a further 41 suspected hepatitis E cases in Doro camp, 2 of whom have died, meaning that none of the camps in Maban County is free of the virus.\n\nThis hepatitis E outbreak was able to take hold because of poor water and sanitation conditions, such as inadequate distribution of clean water, limited access to functioning latrines, and too few hand-washing points in the Maban refugee camps, which host more than 110 000 Sudanese refugees. \"The refugee camps should not only be a place of safety from conflict but also a place where refugees can stay alive and are safe from preventable diseases and outbreaks,\" said Laurence Sailly, MSF Emergency Coordinator in Doro camp.\n\nBecause of Maban county's geographical location, it is a flood plain in the rainy season and a parched wasteland in the dry season. The refugees in these camps are completely reliant on humanitarian assistance for the food, water, and healthcare they need to survive. While continuing to concentrate on the extremely heavy medical workload of caring for hepatitis E patients and treating all the other patients with other pathologies who present in our field hospitals, MSF teams are also carrying out emergency gap-filling activities, such as pumping, treating, and distributing around 2.5 million liters of water per week in Doro camp.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Genotypes 1 and 2 are usually seen in developing countries and cause community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 70 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. The highest seroprevalence rates are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for hepatitis E virus (see: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html). The conditions in the refugee camps in South Sudan are such that, once established, the illness is difficult or impossible to control and eradicate, as described in the MSF statement above.\n\nHepatitis E virus is transmitted mainly through the faecal-oral route due to faecal contamination of drinking water. Other transmission routes include foodborne transmission from ingestion of products derived from infected animals and vertical transmission from a pregnant woman to her fetus. Currently, there is no vaccine available for control of hepatitis E virus infection. Hepatitis E virus infection is self-limiting in normal conditions, and fulminant hepatitis is rare, with only pregnant women being at increased risk. In environments such as the refugee camps in South Sudan, the outcomes are much more serious, especially for pregnant women.\n\nAn interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3q1_. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (03) 20121110.1403808\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (02): chronic 20120917.1296607\nHepatitis E - South Sudan: refugee camps 20120915.1295615\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Batil", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Maban county 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gendrassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "South Sudan 's", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Maban County", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1846069", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - South Sudan (04): (UN) refugee outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1846069", "date": "2013-02-03 16:56:42", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - SOUTH SUDAN: (MABAN) REFUGEE CAMPS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2013\nSource: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) [edited]\nhttp://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=6614&cat=field-news\n\n\nAn epidemic of hepatitis E is escalating across refugee camps in South Sudan's Maban county. Like cholera, the virus spreads in environments with poor sanitation and contaminated water. There is no cure, but its symptoms are treatable.\n\n\"We have been doing everything we can to care for people with hepatitis E [virus infection], but there is no treatment for the disease,\" says Dr. Jose-Luis Dvorzak, MSF Medical Coordinator in Maban County. \"We suspect this outbreak is far from over, and many more people will die.\"\n\nThe 1st cases appeared in June 2012. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1822306", "date": "2013-02-03 16:56:42", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - SOUTH SUDAN: (MABAN) REFUGEE CAMPS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2013\nSource: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) [edited]\nhttp://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=6614&cat=field-news\n\n\nAn epidemic of hepatitis E is escalating across refugee camps in South Sudan's Maban county. To date, Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has treated 3991 patients in its health facilities in the camps and has recorded 88 deaths, including 15 pregnant women. Hepatitis E [virus] causes a liver disease and can lead to acute liver failure and death. It is particularly dangerous for pregnant women. Like cholera, the virus spreads in environments with poor sanitation and contaminated water. There is no cure, but its symptoms are treatable.\n\n\"We have been doing everything we can to care for people with hepatitis E [virus infection], but there is no treatment for the disease,\" says Dr. Jose-Luis Dvorzak, MSF Medical Coordinator in Maban County. \"We suspect this outbreak is far from over, and many more people will die.\"\n\nThe 1st cases appeared in June 2012. Three camps -- Jamam, then Gendrassa and Batil -- have seen the most cases so far. Numbers still have not peaked in Batil camp, where death rates have steadily risen from one or 2 per week in November [2012] to 10 per week in January [2013]. Over the past 2 weeks, MSF has identified a further 41 suspected hepatitis E cases in Doro camp, 2 of whom have died, meaning that none of the camps in Maban County is free of the virus.\n\nThis hepatitis E outbreak was able to take hold because of poor water and sanitation conditions, such as inadequate distribution of clean water, limited access to functioning latrines, and too few hand-washing points in the Maban refugee camps, which host more than 110 000 Sudanese refugees. \"The refugee camps should not only be a place of safety from conflict but also a place where refugees can stay alive and are safe from preventable diseases and outbreaks,\" said Laurence Sailly, MSF Emergency Coordinator in Doro camp.\n\nBecause of Maban county's geographical location, it is a flood plain in the rainy season and a parched wasteland in the dry season. The refugees in these camps are completely reliant on humanitarian assistance for the food, water, and healthcare they need to survive. While continuing to concentrate on the extremely heavy medical workload of caring for hepatitis E patients and treating all the other patients with other pathologies who present in our field hospitals, MSF teams are also carrying out emergency gap-filling activities, such as pumping, treating, and distributing around 2.5 million liters of water per week in Doro camp.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Genotypes 1 and 2 are usually seen in developing countries and cause community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 70 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. The highest seroprevalence rates are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for hepatitis E virus (see: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html). The conditions in the refugee camps in South Sudan are such that, once established, the illness is difficult or impossible to control and eradicate, as described in the MSF statement above.\n\nHepatitis E virus is transmitted mainly through the faecal-oral route due to faecal contamination of drinking water. Other transmission routes include foodborne transmission from ingestion of products derived from infected animals and vertical transmission from a pregnant woman to her fetus. Currently, there is no vaccine available for control of hepatitis E virus infection. Hepatitis E virus infection is self-limiting in normal conditions, and fulminant hepatitis is rare, with only pregnant women being at increased risk. In environments such as the refugee camps in South Sudan, the outcomes are much more serious, especially for pregnant women.\n\nAn interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3q1_. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (03) 20121110.1403808\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (02): chronic 20120917.1296607\nHepatitis E - South Sudan: refugee camps 20120915.1295615\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Batil", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Maban county 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gendrassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "South Sudan 's", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Maban County", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1750302", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis non-A/B/C/D/E: parvovirus-like hybrid", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1750302", "date": "2013-02-03 16:56:42", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - SOUTH SUDAN: (MABAN) REFUGEE CAMPS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2013\nSource: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) [edited]\nhttp://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=6614&cat=field-news\n\n\nAn epidemic of hepatitis E is escalating across refugee camps in South Sudan's Maban county. To date, Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has treated 3991 patients in its health facilities in the camps and has recorded 88 deaths, including 15 pregnant women. Hepatitis E [virus] causes a liver disease and can lead to acute liver failure and death. It is particularly dangerous for pregnant women. Like cholera, the virus spreads in environments with poor sanitation and contaminated water. There is no cure, but its symptoms are treatable.\n\n\"We have been doing everything we can to care for people with hepatitis E [virus infection], but there is no treatment for the disease,\" says Dr. Jose-Luis Dvorzak, MSF Medical Coordinator in Maban County. \"We suspect this outbreak is far from over, and many more people will die.\"\n\nThe 1st cases appeared in June 2012. Three camps -- Jamam, then Gendrassa and Batil -- have seen the most cases so far. Numbers still have not peaked in Batil camp, where death rates have steadily risen from one or 2 per week in November [2012] to 10 per week in January [2013]. Over the past 2 weeks, MSF has identified a further 41 suspected hepatitis E cases in Doro camp, 2 of whom have died, meaning that none of the camps in Maban County is free of the virus.\n\nThis hepatitis E outbreak was able to take hold because of poor water and sanitation conditions, such as inadequate distribution of clean water, limited access to functioning latrines, and too few hand-washing points in the Maban refugee camps, which host more than 110 000 Sudanese refugees. \"The refugee camps should not only be a place of safety from conflict but also a place where refugees can stay alive and are safe from preventable diseases and outbreaks,\" said Laurence Sailly, MSF Emergency Coordinator in Doro camp.\n\nBecause of Maban county's geographical location, it is a flood plain in the rainy season and a parched wasteland in the dry season. The refugees in these camps are completely reliant on humanitarian assistance for the food, water, and healthcare they need to survive. While continuing to concentrate on the extremely heavy medical workload of caring for hepatitis E patients and treating all the other patients with other pathologies who present in our field hospitals, MSF teams are also carrying out emergency gap-filling activities, such as pumping, treating, and distributing around 2.5 million liters of water per week in Doro camp.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is found worldwide, and different genotypes of hepatitis E virus determine differences in epidemiology. Genotypes 1 and 2 are usually seen in developing countries and cause community-level outbreaks, whereas genotype 3 is usually seen in developed countries and does not cause outbreaks. Globally, 70 000 deaths and 3.4 million cases of acute hepatitis E are attributable to infection with hepatitis E virus genotypes 1 and 2. The highest seroprevalence rates are observed in regions where low standards of sanitation increase the risk for transmission of the virus. In Egypt, half the population aged above 5 years is serologically positive for hepatitis E virus (see: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html). The conditions in the refugee camps in South Sudan are such that, once established, the illness is difficult or impossible to control and eradicate, as described in the MSF statement above.\n\nHepatitis E virus is transmitted mainly through the faecal-oral route due to faecal contamination of drinking water. Other transmission routes include foodborne transmission from ingestion of products derived from infected animals and vertical transmission from a pregnant woman to her fetus. Currently, there is no vaccine available for control of hepatitis E virus infection. Hepatitis E virus infection is self-limiting in normal conditions, and fulminant hepatitis is rare, with only pregnant women being at increased risk. In environments such as the refugee camps in South Sudan, the outcomes are much more serious, especially for pregnant women.\n\nAn interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3q1_. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (03) 20121110.1403808\nHepatitis E - South Sudan (02): chronic 20120917.1296607\nHepatitis E - South Sudan: refugee camps 20120915.1295615\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Batil", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Maban county 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gendrassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "South Sudan 's", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Maban County", "country": "South Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1735825", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Sudan: (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1735825", "date": "2013-02-03 16:56:42", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - SOUTH SUDAN: (MABAN) REFUGEE CAMPS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2013\nSource: Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) [edited]\nhttp://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=6614&cat=field-news\n\n\nAn epidemic of hepatitis E is escalating across refugee camps in South Sudan's Maban county. South Sudan (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1403808", "date": "2011-12-24 14:24:26", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - INDIA (2): (GUJARAT), WATER-BORNE\n***********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 2011\nSource: Times of India, Rajkot [edited]\n\nHepatitis E cases on rise in Mehsana town\n-----------------------------------\nThere has been an increase in the number of patients suffering from\nhepatitis E and jaundice in Mehsana town since September [2011].\nKasba, Hydri Chowk, Babi Vado, Faiza No Vado and Siddhapuri Bazaar\nlocalities in old Mehsana town have recorded over 400 cases so far.\nHowever, the health department has put the number at 68.\n\nA resident of Babi Vado said there are as many as 400 people affected\nby stomach ailments and seven are from his family alone. A\nthirty-year-old patient said, \"Water supply pipelines were damaged in\nSeptember when telephone cables were being replaced in our locality.\nThis led to contamination of drinking water. The civic body was\nalerted, but it paid no heed to our complaints. The resident said, \"We\npicketed the municipal office on Wednesday, thus forcing,it to act on\nthe matter.\" Municipal chief officer R P Joshi said, \"We have begun\nreplacing the pipes from Thursday though we have not found leakage\nanywhere. Water in the affected area is being supplied through\ntankers.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E virus is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis\nE is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies\nhave been implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic\ncases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of\nthe virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding in faeces. Person-to-person\ntransmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for sexual transmission\nor for transmission by transfusion. According to the GIDEON database,\naround 2 million cases per year are estimated to occur nationwide in\nIndia.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed by\nrecovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual.\nSymptomatic HEV infection is most common in young adults aged 15-40\nyears. A more fulminant form of hepatitis occasionally develops, with\nmortality rates ranging between 0.5% - 4.0%. Fulminant hepatitis\noccurs more often in pregnancy with a mortality rate of 20% among\nwomen in late pregnancy. Further information can be obtained from the\nWHO website at:\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html.\n\nMehsana is situated in Gujarat state near Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar.\nIt can be located in the map of Gujarat at:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/gujarat/gujarat.htm.\n\nIf this outbreak is due to fractured water supply pipes as suggested,\nbut refuted by the local authority, one might expect hepatitis A virus\ninfection to be equally prevalent. - Mod.CP.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1zT1]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - India: (RN) Jaipur, water-borne 20110713.2119\n2010\n----\nHepatitis E virus - India: (HP) 20100218.0565\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E - India (Kashmir) 20070806.2556\n2005\n----\nHepatitis - India (Maharashtra): hepatitis E conf. 20050329.0908\nHepatitis E - India (Mumbai) 20050107.0044\n2004\n----\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - A\nthirty-year-old patient said, \"Water supply pipelines were damaged in\nSeptember when telephone cables were being replaced in our locality.\nThis led to contamination of drinking water. The civic body was\nalerted, but it paid no heed to our complaints. The resident said, \"We\npicketed the municipal office on Wednesday, thus forcing,it to act on\nthe matter.\" Municipal chief officer R P Joshi said, \"We have begun\nreplacing the pipes from Thursday though we have not found leakage\nanywhere. Water in the affected area is being supplied through\ntankers.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E virus is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis\nE is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies\nhave been implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic\ncases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of\nthe virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding in faeces. Person-to-person\ntransmission is uncommon. A more fulminant form of hepatitis occasionally develops, with\nmortality rates ranging between 0.5% - 4.0%. Fulminant hepatitis\noccurs more often in pregnancy with a mortality rate of 20% among\nwomen in late pregnancy. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic\ncases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of\nthe virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding in faeces. Person-to-person\ntransmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for sexual transmission\nor for transmission by transfusion. According to the GIDEON database,\naround 2 million cases per year are estimated to occur nationwide in\nIndia.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed by\nrecovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual.\nSymptomatic HEV infection is most common in young adults aged 15-40\nyears. A more fulminant form of hepatitis occasionally develops, with\nmortality rates ranging between 0.5% - 4.0%. Fulminant hepatitis\noccurs more often in pregnancy with a mortality rate of 20% among\nwomen in late pregnancy. Further information can be obtained from the\nWHO website at:\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html.\n\nMehsana is situated in Gujarat state near Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar.\nIt can be located in the map of Gujarat at:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/gujarat/gujarat.htm.\n\nIf this outbreak is due to fractured water supply pipes as suggested,\nbut refuted by the local authority, one might expect hepatitis A virus\ninfection to be equally prevalent. - Mod.CP.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1zT1]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - India: (RN) Jaipur, water-borne 20110713.2119\n2010\n----\nHepatitis E virus - India: (HP) 20100218.0565\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\n.................................................sb/cp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gandhinagar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "symptomatic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hydri Chowk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ahmedabad", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1176651", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Jaundice - India (03): (MA) Kolhapur, hepatitis E conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1176651", "date": "2011-12-24 14:24:26", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - INDIA (2): (GUJARAT), WATER-BORNE\n***********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 2011\nSource: Times of India, Rajkot [edited]\n\nHepatitis E cases on rise in Mehsana town\n-----------------------------------\nThere has been an increase in the number of patients suffering from\nhepatitis E and jaundice in Mehsana town since September [2011].\nKasba, Hydri Chowk, Babi Vado, Faiza No Vado and Siddhapuri Bazaar\nlocalities in old Mehsana town have recorded over 400 cases so far.\nHowever, the health department has put the number at 68.\n\nA resident of Babi Vado said there are as many as 400 people affected\nby stomach ailments and seven are from his family alone. A\nthirty-year-old patient said, \"Water supply pipelines were damaged in\nSeptember when telephone cables were being replaced in our locality.\nThis led to contamination of drinking water. The civic body was\nalerted, but it paid no heed to our complaints. The resident said, \"We\npicketed the municipal office on Wednesday, thus forcing,it to act on\nthe matter.\" Municipal chief officer R P Joshi said, \"We have begun\nreplacing the pipes from Thursday though we have not found leakage\nanywhere. Water in the affected area is being supplied through\ntankers.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E virus is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis\nE is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies\nhave been implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic\ncases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of\nthe virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding in faeces. Person-to-person\ntransmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for sexual transmission\nor for transmission by transfusion. According to the GIDEON database,\naround 2 million cases per year are estimated to occur nationwide in\nIndia.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed by\nrecovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual.\nSymptomatic HEV infection is most common in young adults aged 15-40\nyears. A more fulminant form of hepatitis occasionally develops, with\nmortality rates ranging between 0.5% - 4.0%. Fulminant hepatitis\noccurs more often in pregnancy with a mortality rate of 20% among\nwomen in late pregnancy. Further information can be obtained from the\nWHO website at:\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html.\n\nMehsana is situated in Gujarat state near Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar.\nIt can be located in the map of Gujarat at:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/gujarat/gujarat.htm.\n\nIf this outbreak is due to fractured water supply pipes as suggested,\nbut refuted by the local authority, one might expect hepatitis A virus\ninfection to be equally prevalent. - A\nthirty-year-old patient said, \"Water supply pipelines were damaged in\nSeptember when telephone cables were being replaced in our locality.\nThis led to contamination of drinking water. The civic body was\nalerted, but it paid no heed to our complaints. The resident said, \"We\npicketed the municipal office on Wednesday, thus forcing,it to act on\nthe matter.\" Municipal chief officer R P Joshi said, \"We have begun\nreplacing the pipes from Thursday though we have not found leakage\nanywhere. Water in the affected area is being supplied through\ntankers.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E virus is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis\nE is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies\nhave been implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic\ncases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of\nthe virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding in faeces. Person-to-person\ntransmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for sexual transmission\nor for transmission by transfusion. According to the GIDEON database,\naround 2 million cases per year are estimated to occur nationwide in\nIndia.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed by\nrecovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual.\nSymptomatic HEV infection is most common in young adults aged 15-40\nyears. A more fulminant form of hepatitis occasionally develops, with\nmortality rates ranging between 0.5% - 4.0%. Fulminant hepatitis\noccurs more often in pregnancy with a mortality rate of 20% among\nwomen in late pregnancy. India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\n.................................................sb/cp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gandhinagar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "symptomatic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hydri Chowk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ahmedabad", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "962332", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E, lagomorphs - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=962332", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newquay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "952328", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis C - UK (05): (England) E. Lancs.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=952328", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newquay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "786083", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - India: (RN) Jaipur, water-borne", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=786083", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
