If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newquay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "753757", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Uganda: Karamoja", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=753757", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. France: (SE), autochthonous & food-borne", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=697667", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. UK (03): England", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=564084", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hepatitis d", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newquay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "562496", "headline": "PRO/AH> Hepatitis E, foodborne - UK (02): (England) background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=562496", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=559379", "date": "2010-10-23 23:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, FOODBORNE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Oct 2010\nSource: Daily Telegraph online [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/8081387/Virus-warning-over-undercooked-pork-after-three-die.html>\n\n\nBritons warned not to eat undercooked pork\n------------------------------------------\nA rare [type] of the liver disease, hepatitis E, has killed 3 people\nin Cornwall and caused at least 55 more across the UK to fall ill.\nHepatitis E is generally thought to be caused by poor sanitary\nconditions and previously it had been assumed that British sufferers\nhad caught the disease abroad.\n\nBut Dr Harry Dalton, a consultant gastroenterologist at Royal\nCornwall Hospital Trust, said the recent patients he had seen did not\nfit the usual criteria. He said: \"Not only had the patients not\ntravelled abroad but they didn't fit the normal age range for the\nvirus. \"In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.\" He believes that the main cause is\ncontact with raw pork and is now researching the link.\n\nPatients with liver problems admitted to hospital will be checked to\nsee if the problems had been caused by hepatitis E [virus infection].\nHowever a spokesman for the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said: \"The\nSouth West Peninsula HPA previously worked with Dr Harry Dalton,\nRoyal Cornwall Hospital Trust to investigate a number of hepatitis E\ncases from Dec 2009 to March 2010 in the Cornwall area. The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.\"\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. He added: \"The\nmessage is not to not eat pork, but to simply make sure it is cooked\nproperly and that hands are washed thoroughly after handling it raw.\"\nDr Dalton believes hepatitis E could be affecting as many as 1200\npeople in the UK every year. He said: \"Victims become jaundiced and\nthis has resulted in patients being misdiagnosed as suffering [from]\nalcohol abuse.\n\nDr Dalton said there have been 3 deaths related to hepatitis E\ninfection over the last 7 years and around 60 cases of hepatitis E in\nCornwall and Devon between 1999-2010, the vast majority of whom have\nbeen seen since 2005. One victim of the disease, a 59-year-old man,\ncontracted hepatitis E and died in July 2006. His 63-year-old wife,\nfrom Newquay in Cornwall, said he started feeling ill while he was\nworking at a factory next door to a pig farm. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: \"Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA\". A. R. Feagins et al., J. Gen. Virol. 88 (2007), 912-917).\n\nCornwall and Devon can be located at the extreme south-west in the\nmap of the counties of England at:\n<http://printable-maps.blogspot.com/2008/09/uk-map-showing-counties.html>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the South of England is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0e60> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK (02) 20080501.1503\nHepatitis E, world cruise - UK 20080405.1249\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\n...................cp/ejp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=453208", "date": "2009-09-18 19:00:03", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 18 Sep 2009\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com>\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Hepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage\n20090917.3267\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following background data on hepatitis E in France were abstracted\nfrom the Gideon database.\n\nIncidence\n---------\n- 46 cases were confirmed during 2002 to 2004 -- including 16 imported cases.\n- 62 cases were confirmed in southwestern France during 2003 to 2007.\n- 369 cases were reported during 2006 to 2008: 264 autochthonous, 51\nimported and 54 unclassified.\n\nDuring 2001 to 2002, autochthonous infection was documented in 2.72\npercent of acute hepatitis patients in the Midi Pyrenees area.\n\nA case of transfusion-related hepatitis E infection was reported in 2006\n\nRisk factors for hepatitis E in France have included water consumption\nfrom a personal water supply, consumption of uncooked shellfish, and\nthe recent acquisition of a pet pig.\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 2.5 percent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_) livers in southeastern\nFrance (2009 publication)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 2.6 percent of pregnant women\n- 3.2 percent of blood donors (2007 publication)\n- 16.6 percent of blood donors in southwestern France (2008 publication)\n- 40 percent of piglets in southern France (2009 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n- 1983 to 1984 -- outbreaks of presumed hepatitis E infection were\nreported among French soldiers in Chad.\n2008 (publication year) -- an outbreak (2 cases) in Southern France\nwas related to ingestion of raw pig meat.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[Professor Berger has indicated that he will supply primary references\nfor these data on request. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage 20090917.3267\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - Spain 20070215.0561\n........................................cp/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "452638", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - USA: (TX) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=452638", "date": "2009-09-18 19:00:03", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 18 Sep 2009\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com>\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Hepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage\n20090917.3267\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following background data on hepatitis E in France were abstracted\nfrom the Gideon database.\n\nIncidence\n---------\n- 46 cases were confirmed during 2002 to 2004 -- including 16 imported cases.\n- 62 cases were confirmed in southwestern France during 2003 to 2007.\n- 369 cases were reported during 2006 to 2008: 264 autochthonous, 51\nimported and 54 unclassified.\n\nDuring 2001 to 2002, autochthonous infection was documented in 2.72\npercent of acute hepatitis patients in the Midi Pyrenees area.\n\nA case of transfusion-related hepatitis E infection was reported in 2006\n\nRisk factors for hepatitis E in France have included water consumption\nfrom a personal water supply, consumption of uncooked shellfish, and\nthe recent acquisition of a pet pig.\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 2.5 percent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_) livers in southeastern\nFrance (2009 publication)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 2.6 percent of pregnant women\n- 3.2 percent of blood donors (2007 publication)\n- 16.6 percent of blood donors in southwestern France (2008 publication)\n- 40 percent of piglets in southern France (2009 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n- 1983 to 1984 -- outbreaks of presumed hepatitis E infection were\nreported among French soldiers in Chad.\n2008 (publication year) -- an outbreak (2 cases) in Southern France\nwas related to ingestion of raw pig meat.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[Professor Berger has indicated that he will supply primary references\nfor these data on request. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage 20090917.3267\n2007\n----\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - UK (England) 20070218.0615\nHepatitis E, porcine carriers - Spain 20070215.0561\n........................................cp/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage\n20090917.3267\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following background data on hepatitis E in France were abstracted\nfrom the Gideon database.\n\nIncidence\n---------\n- 46 cases were confirmed during 2002 to 2004 -- including 16 imported cases.\n- 62 cases were confirmed in southwestern France during 2003 to 2007.\n- 369 cases were reported during 2006 to 2008: 264 autochthonous, 51\nimported and 54 unclassified.\n\nDuring 2001 to 2002, autochthonous infection was documented in 2.72\npercent of acute hepatitis patients in the Midi Pyrenees area.\n\nA case of transfusion-related hepatitis E infection was reported in 2006\n\nRisk factors for hepatitis E in France have included water consumption\nfrom a personal water supply, consumption of uncooked shellfish, and\nthe recent acquisition of a pet pig.\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 2.5 percent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_) livers in southeastern\nFrance (2009 publication)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 2.6 percent of pregnant women\n- 3.2 percent of blood donors (2007 publication)\n- 16.6 percent of blood donors in southwestern France (2008 publication)\n- 40 percent of piglets in southern France (2009 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n- 1983 to 1984 -- outbreaks of presumed hepatitis E infection were\nreported among French soldiers in Chad.\n2008 (publication year) -- an outbreak (2 cases) in Southern France\nwas related to ingestion of raw pig meat.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[Professor Berger has indicated that he will supply primary references\nfor these data on request. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "293736", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=293736", "date": "2008-10-17 16:00:34", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - UGANDA (11): (KITGUM)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 16 Oct 2008\nSource: The New Vision, Uganda [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/16/654882>\n\n\nKitgum gets 64 new cases of hepatitis E\n---------------------------------------\nSixty-four new cases of the deadly hepatitis E virus were reported\nthis week in Kitgum district. This, however, is a reduction in the\ninfections from 90 cases reported the previous week. According to the\nMinistry of Health, the disease is receding. The ministry said the\ncumulative number of hepatitis [E] infections now stands at 8617.\n\nOnly one new death was reported in Lokung sub-county in the week,\nwhich brings the cumulative deaths to 127 in 41 weeks. \"On the whole,\nthe trend of the hepatitis E outbreak continues to recede in all the\nsub-counties of Kitgum district,\" a statement from the ministry\nstated. Layamo sub-county had 15 of the new cases, while Agoro and\nPadibe reported 10 each. Kitgum Town Council had 6, Mucwini had 5,\nwhile Lagoro and Paloga reported 4 each. Madi Opei, Kitgum Matidi,\nand Namukora reported 2 cases each, while Lokung, Akwang, Omiya\nAnyima, and Amida reported one case each. The statement said Layamo,\nAgoro, Padibe, and Kitgum town council had registered the highest\nnumber of cases.\n\nThe disease, which is spread through consumption of food and fluids\ncontaminated with infected faecal matter, broke out in October last\nyear [2007]. The most affected were people living in camps for the\ninternally displaced and those returning to their villages after the\nLRA [Lord's Resistance Army] insurgency.\n\nThe disease's long incubation period had been responsible for its\nspread, according to the Minister of Health, Dr Stephen Mallinga. He\nsaid recently that the heavy rains in Kitgum had increased\ntransmission of the disease because people returning from camps had\nlimited safe drinking water. The problem was compounded by lack of\npit latrines, with people easing themselves in bushes from where the\nvirus found its way into the water sources. According to Mallinga,\nthere was need for the water ministry to sink more boreholes. He said\nthe Min Health was working with UNICEF (UN Children's Fund) and the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) to provide better services in the region.\n\n[Byline: Anne Mugisa)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Although the outbreak of hepatitis E infection in the Kitgum\ndistrict of Uganda may be beginning to decline, the number of new\ncases is substantial, bringing the overall total in the Kitgum\ndistrict to 8617. Heavy rainfall, movement of internally displaced\npersons (IDPs), and the consequences of internal strife are combining\nto frustrate the efforts of the Ugandan authorities to provide\nadequate sanitation and sources of clean water in this district of Uganda.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum district in the north\nof the country can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443346&v=1.5,36,5>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (10): (Pader) 20081014.3256\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (09): (Kitgum) 20080905.2777\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (08): (Kitgum) 20080813.2511\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (07): (Kitgum) 20080806.2413\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (06): (Kitgum) 20080804.2385\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (05): (Kitgum) 20080716.2159\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (04): (Kitgum) 20080620.1919\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (03): (Kitgum) 20080529.1737\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. According to Mallinga,\nthere was need for the water ministry to sink more boreholes. This, however, is a reduction in the\ninfections from 90 cases reported the previous week. According to the\nMinistry of Health, the disease is receding. The ministry said the\ncumulative number of hepatitis [E] infections now stands at 8617.\n\nOnly one new death was reported in Lokung sub-county in the week,\nwhich brings the cumulative deaths to 127 in 41 weeks. \"On the whole,\nthe trend of the hepatitis E outbreak continues to recede in all the\nsub-counties of Kitgum district,\" a statement from the ministry\nstated. Layamo sub-county had 15 of the new cases, while Agoro and\nPadibe reported 10 each. Kitgum Town Council had 6, Mucwini had 5,\nwhile Lagoro and Paloga reported 4 each. Madi Opei, Kitgum Matidi,\nand Namukora reported 2 cases each, while Lokung, Akwang, Omiya\nAnyima, and Amida reported one case each. The statement said Layamo,\nAgoro, Padibe, and Kitgum town council had registered the highest\nnumber of cases.\n\nThe disease, which is spread through consumption of food and fluids\ncontaminated with infected faecal matter, broke out in October last\nyear [2007]. The most affected were people living in camps for the\ninternally displaced and those returning to their villages after the\nLRA [Lord's Resistance Army] insurgency.\n\nThe disease's long incubation period had been responsible for its\nspread, according to the Minister of Health, Dr Stephen Mallinga. He\nsaid recently that the heavy rains in Kitgum had increased\ntransmission of the disease because people returning from camps had\nlimited safe drinking water. The problem was compounded by lack of\npit latrines, with people easing themselves in bushes from where the\nvirus found its way into the water sources. According to Mallinga,\nthere was need for the water ministry to sink more boreholes. He said\nthe Min Health was working with UNICEF (UN Children's Fund) and the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) to provide better services in the region.\n\n[Byline: Anne Mugisa)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Although the outbreak of hepatitis E infection in the Kitgum\ndistrict of Uganda may be beginning to decline, the number of new\ncases is substantial, bringing the overall total in the Kitgum\ndistrict to 8617. Heavy rainfall, movement of internally displaced\npersons (IDPs), and the consequences of internal strife are combining\nto frustrate the efforts of the Ugandan authorities to provide\nadequate sanitation and sources of clean water in this district of Uganda.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum district in the north\nof the country can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443346&v=1.5,36,5>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (10): (Pader) 20081014.3256\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (09): (Kitgum) 20080905.2777\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (08): (Kitgum) 20080813.2511\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (07): (Kitgum) 20080806.2413\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (06): (Kitgum) 20080804.2385\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (05): (Kitgum) 20080716.2159\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (04): (Kitgum) 20080620.1919\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (03): (Kitgum) 20080529.1737\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This, however, is a reduction in the\ninfections from 90 cases reported the previous week. According to the\nMinistry of Health, the disease is receding. The ministry said the\ncumulative number of hepatitis [E] infections now stands at 8617.\n\nOnly one new death was reported in Lokung sub-county in the week,\nwhich brings the cumulative deaths to 127 in 41 weeks. \"On the whole,\nthe trend of the hepatitis E outbreak continues to recede in all the\nsub-counties of Kitgum district,\" a statement from the ministry\nstated. The statement said Layamo,\nAgoro, Padibe, and Kitgum town council had registered the highest\nnumber of cases.\n\nThe disease, which is spread through consumption of food and fluids\ncontaminated with infected faecal matter, broke out in October last\nyear [2007]. The most affected were people living in camps for the\ninternally displaced and those returning to their villages after the\nLRA [Lord's Resistance Army] insurgency.\n\nThe disease's long incubation period had been responsible for its\nspread, according to the Minister of Health, Dr Stephen Mallinga. He\nsaid recently that the heavy rains in Kitgum had increased\ntransmission of the disease because people returning from camps had\nlimited safe drinking water. The problem was compounded by lack of\npit latrines, with people easing themselves in bushes from where the\nvirus found its way into the water sources. According to Mallinga,\nthere was need for the water ministry to sink more boreholes. He said\nthe Min Health was working with UNICEF (UN Children's Fund) and the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) to provide better services in the region.\n\n[Byline: Anne Mugisa)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Although the outbreak of hepatitis E infection in the Kitgum\ndistrict of Uganda may be beginning to decline, the number of new\ncases is substantial, bringing the overall total in the Kitgum\ndistrict to 8617. Heavy rainfall, movement of internally displaced\npersons (IDPs), and the consequences of internal strife are combining\nto frustrate the efforts of the Ugandan authorities to provide\nadequate sanitation and sources of clean water in this district of Uganda.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum district in the north\nof the country can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443346&v=1.5,36,5>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (10): (Pader) 20081014.3256\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (09): (Kitgum) 20080905.2777\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (08): (Kitgum) 20080813.2511\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (07): (Kitgum) 20080806.2413\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (06): (Kitgum) 20080804.2385\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (05): (Kitgum) 20080716.2159\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (04): (Kitgum) 20080620.1919\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (03): (Kitgum) 20080529.1737\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "8617-03-16 00:00:00", "8617-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Akwang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kitgum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lokung", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "119344", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Uganda (10): (Pader)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=119344", "date": "2008-05-29 12:00:22", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - UGANDA (03): (KITGUM)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 May 2008\nSource: The New Vision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/16/630359>\n\n\nHepatitis kills 4 more\n----------------------\nThe number of people killed by hepatitis E in Kitgum district has\nincreased to 35 from 31 in the past one week, reports Chris Ocowun.\nThe dead are mainly pregnant women, while the total number of those\ninfected is 1797.\n\n\"The virus, thought to have been brought from South Sudan, was first\ndetected in Lamwo County. It spread to Agoro, Mucwini, Paloga,\nPotika, Padibe, and Lukung sub-counties and is now threatening Kitgum\ntown council,\" the deputy resident district commissioner, Sylvester\nOpira, said on Tuesday [27 May 2008]. \"We are urging people to visit\nhealth centres if they feel feverish. We are also advising couples to\ndelay conception.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The number of cases of hepatitis E reported in the initial account\nof the outbreak in the region of Uganda bordering Sudan (see\nreference below) has increased now from 314 cases and 11 deaths to\nthe current 1797 cases and 35 deaths.\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV),\nwhich is transmitted in much the same way as other enteric viruses.\nHEV is found in the faeces of people and animals with hepatitis E.\nHEV is spread by eating or drinking contaminated food or water.\nTransmission from person to person may occur.\n\nHepatitis E outbreaks have occurred worldwide in recent years and may\nbe increasing in frequency. The signs and symptoms of HEV infection\nare loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, discoloured urine, jaundice,\nand abdominal pain. There is, however, no chronic (long term)\ninfection. Hepatitis E is more severe among pregnant women,\nespecially in the 3rd trimester.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum in the north of the\ncountry can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1797-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-05-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lamwo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kitgum", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "109456", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Uganda (09): (Kitgum)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=109456", "date": "2008-05-29 12:00:22", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - UGANDA (03): (KITGUM)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 May 2008\nSource: The New Vision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/16/630359>\n\n\nHepatitis kills 4 more\n----------------------\nThe number of people killed by hepatitis E in Kitgum district has\nincreased to 35 from 31 in the past one week, reports Chris Ocowun.\nThe dead are mainly pregnant women, while the total number of those\ninfected is 1797.\n\n\"The virus, thought to have been brought from South Sudan, was first\ndetected in Lamwo County. It spread to Agoro, Mucwini, Paloga,\nPotika, Padibe, and Lukung sub-counties and is now threatening Kitgum\ntown council,\" the deputy resident district commissioner, Sylvester\nOpira, said on Tuesday [27 May 2008]. \"We are urging people to visit\nhealth centres if they feel feverish. We are also advising couples to\ndelay conception.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The number of cases of hepatitis E reported in the initial account\nof the outbreak in the region of Uganda bordering Sudan (see\nreference below) has increased now from 314 cases and 11 deaths to\nthe current 1797 cases and 35 deaths.\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV),\nwhich is transmitted in much the same way as other enteric viruses.\nHEV is found in the faeces of people and animals with hepatitis E.\nHEV is spread by eating or drinking contaminated food or water.\nTransmission from person to person may occur.\n\nHepatitis E outbreaks have occurred worldwide in recent years and may\nbe increasing in frequency. The signs and symptoms of HEV infection\nare loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, discoloured urine, jaundice,\nand abdominal pain. There is, however, no chronic (long term)\ninfection. Hepatitis E is more severe among pregnant women,\nespecially in the 3rd trimester.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum in the north of the\ncountry can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It spread to Agoro, Mucwini, Paloga,\nPotika, Padibe, and Lukung sub-counties and is now threatening Kitgum\ntown council,\" the deputy resident district commissioner, Sylvester\nOpira, said on Tuesday [27 May 2008]. \"We are urging people to visit\nhealth centres if they feel feverish. We are also advising couples to\ndelay conception.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The number of cases of hepatitis E reported in the initial account\nof the outbreak in the region of Uganda bordering Sudan (see\nreference below) has increased now from 314 cases and 11 deaths to\nthe current 1797 cases and 35 deaths.\n\nHepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV),\nwhich is transmitted in much the same way as other enteric viruses.\nHEV is found in the faeces of people and animals with hepatitis E.\nHEV is spread by eating or drinking contaminated food or water.\nTransmission from person to person may occur.\n\nHepatitis E outbreaks have occurred worldwide in recent years and may\nbe increasing in frequency. The signs and symptoms of HEV infection\nare loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, discoloured urine, jaundice,\nand abdominal pain. There is, however, no chronic (long term)\ninfection. Hepatitis E is more severe among pregnant women,\nespecially in the 3rd trimester.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum in the north of the\ncountry can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612\nHepatitis E virus - Uganda 20080304.0894\n...................................cp/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1797-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-05-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lamwo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kitgum", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "79362", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=79362", "date": "2007-09-20 03:00:08", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - EUROPE (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Sep 2007\nFrom: Benjamin Cowie <Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n\nre: ProMED-mail post \"Hepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\"\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Moderator's referred question from Dr Robert McNair Scott is an\ninteresting one, which has been the subject of previous research. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. Med J Aust 2005; 183(9): 491.\n--\nDr Benjamin C Cowie MBBS GradDipClinEpi FRACP\nInfectious Diseases Physician, NHMRC PhD Scholar\nVictorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory\n10 Wreckyn Street, North Melbourne\nVictoria 3051, Australia\n<Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes Dr Cowie's well-documented contribution to this\nthread, although it does not relate directly to the situation in Europe.\nHis commentary, however, suggests a need for enhanced HEV surveillance in\nthe European region. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\n2004\n---\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nagasaki) 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n---\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\n2002\n---\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\n2001\n---\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n...............cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6.
