For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1560-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2367-08-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chadha MS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nagasaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Wong DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "70523", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E, world cruise - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=70523", "date": "2007-09-20 03:00:08", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - EUROPE (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Sep 2007\nFrom: Benjamin Cowie <Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n\nre: ProMED-mail post \"Hepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\"\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Moderator's referred question from Dr Robert McNair Scott is an\ninteresting one, which has been the subject of previous research. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. Med J Aust 2005; 183(9): 491.\n--\nDr Benjamin C Cowie MBBS GradDipClinEpi FRACP\nInfectious Diseases Physician, NHMRC PhD Scholar\nVictorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory\n10 Wreckyn Street, North Melbourne\nVictoria 3051, Australia\n<Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes Dr Cowie's well-documented contribution to this\nthread, although it does not relate directly to the situation in Europe.\nHis commentary, however, suggests a need for enhanced HEV surveillance in\nthe European region. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\n2004\n---\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nagasaki) 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n---\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\n2002\n---\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\n2001\n---\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n...............cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1560-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2367-08-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chadha MS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nagasaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Wong DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "63941", "headline": "PRO> Hepatitis E virus - Sub-Saharan Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=63941", "date": "2007-09-20 03:00:08", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - EUROPE (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Sep 2007\nFrom: Benjamin Cowie <Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n\nre: ProMED-mail post \"Hepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\"\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Moderator's referred question from Dr Robert McNair Scott is an\ninteresting one, which has been the subject of previous research. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. Med J Aust 2005; 183(9): 491.\n--\nDr Benjamin C Cowie MBBS GradDipClinEpi FRACP\nInfectious Diseases Physician, NHMRC PhD Scholar\nVictorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory\n10 Wreckyn Street, North Melbourne\nVictoria 3051, Australia\n<Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes Dr Cowie's well-documented contribution to this\nthread, although it does not relate directly to the situation in Europe.\nHis commentary, however, suggests a need for enhanced HEV surveillance in\nthe European region. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\n2004\n---\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nagasaki) 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n---\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\n2002\n---\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\n2001\n---\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n...............cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. Med J Aust 2005; 183(9): 491.\n--\nDr Benjamin C Cowie MBBS GradDipClinEpi FRACP\nInfectious Diseases Physician, NHMRC PhD Scholar\nVictorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory\n10 Wreckyn Street, North Melbourne\nVictoria 3051, Australia\n<Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes Dr Cowie's well-documented contribution to this\nthread, although it does not relate directly to the situation in Europe.\nHis commentary, however, suggests a need for enhanced HEV surveillance in\nthe European region. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\n2004\n---\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nagasaki) 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n---\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\n2002\n---\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\n2001\n---\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n...............cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1560-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2367-08-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chadha MS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nagasaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Wong DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "27779", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=27779", "date": "2007-09-20 03:00:08", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - EUROPE (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Sep 2007\nFrom: Benjamin Cowie <Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n\nre: ProMED-mail post \"Hepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\"\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Moderator's referred question from Dr Robert McNair Scott is an\ninteresting one, which has been the subject of previous research. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in \"non-endemic\" countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. Med J Aust 2005; 183(9): 491.\n--\nDr Benjamin C Cowie MBBS GradDipClinEpi FRACP\nInfectious Diseases Physician, NHMRC PhD Scholar\nVictorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory\n10 Wreckyn Street, North Melbourne\nVictoria 3051, Australia\n<Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n[ProMED-mail welcomes Dr Cowie's well-documented contribution to this\nthread, although it does not relate directly to the situation in Europe.\nHis commentary, however, suggests a need for enhanced HEV surveillance in\nthe European region. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093\n2004\n---\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nagasaki) 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n2003\n---\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\n2002\n---\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\n2001\n---\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n...............cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1560-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1955-03-16 00:00:00", "2367-08-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chadha MS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nagasaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Wong DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "21287", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - India (Kashmir)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=21287", "date": "2006-10-18 00:00:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - CONGO DR (EQUATEUR)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Oct 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Wed 18 Oct 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2c2172e0b4ab34ebf1296bfffd51baaa.htm>\n\nAt least 724 000 people in Equateur Province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC) are at risk after an outbreak of hepatitis E, which has killed\n13 people and infected 341 others since July 2006, an official of the\nUnited Nations World Health Organization (WHO) said.\nHepatitis E is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food\nsupplies have been implicated in major outbreaks, according to WHO. A WHO\nepidemiologist, Dr Jean Robert Likofata, said on Tuesday [17 Oct 2006] in\nthe capital, Kinshasa, that 4 health zones around the town of Gemena in\nEquateur were threatened by the disease, which has an incubation period of\nbetween 3 and 8 weeks. He said the whole province was threatened by this\nepidemic because Gemena was an \"epicentre\", as it is a market town,\nfacilitating contact with almost the whole population in the area.\nMoreover, Likofata said cases of hepatitis E had been recorded up to 65 km\nsouthwest in the health zone of Bwamanda; 105 km west in the Tandaba zone\nand at least 44 km northwest in the health zones of Bogose and Nubea. \"This\ndisease is transmitted through contaminated water, especially when hygiene\nis not good when it comes to the washing of hands,\" Likofata said. \"And at\nthis market, which dominates Gemena town, you have businessmen coming from\nall around the province.\"\nLikofata led a medical team to Gemena when the first cases were reported in\nJuly 2006, to inspect samples that were later sent to a laboratory in\nKinshasa. Initially, Likofata said, the outbreak was suspected to be yellow\nfever until the laboratory results confirmed it was hepatitis E. He said\nthose affected initially exhibit flu-like symptoms, with high fever, nausea\nand loss of appetite, which could last a week. The next phase is yellowing\neyes, pale faeces and dark urine consistent with liver disease. There is no\neffective treatment aside from bed-rest and fluid replacement, so\nprevention is key.\nBesides sharing information about the disease's symptoms with staff in the\nmain health centres in Equateur, the medical team also conducted awareness\ncampaigns to inform the public about the importance of hygiene in the\nprevention of hepatitis E.\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Hepatitis E virus, has caused large epidemics of enterically transmitted\nself-limiting acute viral hepatitis throughout the Indian subcontinent,\nsoutheast and central Asia, the Middle East, parts of Africa, and Mexico.\nSeroprevalence surveys indicate that the virus is prevalent elsewhere\nsuggesting the existence of strains of differing virulence.\nHepatitis E is a cause of considerable morbidity and mortality and poses a\nmajor health problem in endemic regions. Hepatitis E epidemics are\nwaterborne outbreaks. During these outbreaks, overall attack rates range\nfrom 1 to 15 percent, being higher among adults (3 to 30 percent) than\namong children (0.2 to 10 percent). The outbreaks are characterized by a\nparticularly high attack rate and mortality among pregnant women. In\nnon-endemic regions, hepatitis E accounts for less than 1 percent of\nreported cases of acute viral hepatitis.\nThe clinical disease in humans is typical of viral hepatitis. The liver\nappears to be the only target organ of infection, and its extrahepatic\nmanifestations have been rare. The incubation period ranges from 15 to 50\ndays. The preicteric phase lasts for 1-10 (average 3-4) days, and\ngastrointestinal symptoms, such as epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting,\nare frequently reported. The icteric phase begins abruptly, with the\nappearance of jaundice, dark urine and clay-coloured stools. In\nuncomplicated cases these symptoms last 12-15 days, and complete recovery\nusually takes place within 1 month. About half the patients develop fever\nand 2/3 complain of arthralgia.\nClinical studies have shown that elevation of serum alanine\naminotransferase levels occur as a single peak preceding or coinciding with\nthe onset of jaundice, which is similar to most other forms of viral\nhepatitis. In disease-endemic regions, this infection constitutes an\nimportant cause of fulminant hepatic damage. Pregnant women, particularly\nthose in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters, are more frequently affected during\nhepatitis E outbreaks and have a worse outcome. Mortality rates among\npregnant women, especially those infected in the 3rd trimester, range\nbetween 5 and 25 percent. Frequency of abortions, stillbirths and neonatal\ndeaths is also increased among hepatitis E virus-infected pregnant women.\nControl of hepatitis E outbreaks consists predominantly of measures to\ninterrupt water-borne transmission of disease and appropriate education of\nthe population at risk.\nA map of the Democratic Republic of Congo showing the location of Gemena in\nthe north of Equateur Provincec an be accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nHepatitis E - Chad (Eastern)20050822.2477\nHepatitis A & E - India (Hyderabad) 20050328.0894\nHepatitis E - India (Mumbai) 20050107.0044\n2004\n----\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq 20040602.1505\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq (02) 20040924.2642\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) 20040819.2299\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) (02) 20040831.2424\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(03) 20040906.2490\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(04) 20040915.2570\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(05) 20040927.2667\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) 20040810.2209\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (02) 20040827.2398\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (03): background 20040827.2399\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (04) 20040830.2419\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (05) 20040908.2506\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur)(06) 20040929.2689\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nag... 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n...........................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tandaba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gemena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equateur Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Equateur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8378", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E - Afghanistan (Laghman)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8378", "date": "2006-10-18 00:00:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - CONGO DR (EQUATEUR)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Oct 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Wed 18 Oct 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2c2172e0b4ab34ebf1296bfffd51baaa.htm>\n\nAt least 724 000 people in Equateur Province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC) are at risk after an outbreak of hepatitis E, which has killed\n13 people and infected 341 others since July 2006, an official of the\nUnited Nations World Health Organization (WHO) said.\nHepatitis E is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food\nsupplies have been implicated in major outbreaks, according to WHO. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tandaba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gemena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equateur Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Equateur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8228", "headline": "PRO> Hepatitis E - Nepal (03): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8228", "date": "2006-10-18 00:00:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - CONGO DR (EQUATEUR)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Oct 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Wed 18 Oct 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2c2172e0b4ab34ebf1296bfffd51baaa.htm>\n\nAt least 724 000 people in Equateur Province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC) are at risk after an outbreak of hepatitis E, which has killed\n13 people and infected 341 others since July 2006, an official of the\nUnited Nations World Health Organization (WHO) said.\nHepatitis E is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food\nsupplies have been implicated in major outbreaks, according to WHO. A WHO\nepidemiologist, Dr Jean Robert Likofata, said on Tuesday [17 Oct 2006] in\nthe capital, Kinshasa, that 4 health zones around the town of Gemena in\nEquateur were threatened by the disease, which has an incubation period of\nbetween 3 and 8 weeks. He said the whole province was threatened by this\nepidemic because Gemena was an \"epicentre\", as it is a market town,\nfacilitating contact with almost the whole population in the area.\nMoreover, Likofata said cases of hepatitis E had been recorded up to 65 km\nsouthwest in the health zone of Bwamanda; 105 km west in the Tandaba zone\nand at least 44 km northwest in the health zones of Bogose and Nubea. \"This\ndisease is transmitted through contaminated water, especially when hygiene\nis not good when it comes to the washing of hands,\" Likofata said. \"And at\nthis market, which dominates Gemena town, you have businessmen coming from\nall around the province.\"\nLikofata led a medical team to Gemena when the first cases were reported in\nJuly 2006, to inspect samples that were later sent to a laboratory in\nKinshasa. Initially, Likofata said, the outbreak was suspected to be yellow\nfever until the laboratory results confirmed it was hepatitis E. He said\nthose affected initially exhibit flu-like symptoms, with high fever, nausea\nand loss of appetite, which could last a week. The next phase is yellowing\neyes, pale faeces and dark urine consistent with liver disease. There is no\neffective treatment aside from bed-rest and fluid replacement, so\nprevention is key.\nBesides sharing information about the disease's symptoms with staff in the\nmain health centres in Equateur, the medical team also conducted awareness\ncampaigns to inform the public about the importance of hygiene in the\nprevention of hepatitis E.\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Hepatitis E virus, has caused large epidemics of enterically transmitted\nself-limiting acute viral hepatitis throughout the Indian subcontinent,\nsoutheast and central Asia, the Middle East, parts of Africa, and Mexico.\nSeroprevalence surveys indicate that the virus is prevalent elsewhere\nsuggesting the existence of strains of differing virulence.\nHepatitis E is a cause of considerable morbidity and mortality and poses a\nmajor health problem in endemic regions. Hepatitis E epidemics are\nwaterborne outbreaks. During these outbreaks, overall attack rates range\nfrom 1 to 15 percent, being higher among adults (3 to 30 percent) than\namong children (0.2 to 10 percent). The outbreaks are characterized by a\nparticularly high attack rate and mortality among pregnant women. In\nnon-endemic regions, hepatitis E accounts for less than 1 percent of\nreported cases of acute viral hepatitis.\nThe clinical disease in humans is typical of viral hepatitis. The liver\nappears to be the only target organ of infection, and its extrahepatic\nmanifestations have been rare. The incubation period ranges from 15 to 50\ndays. The preicteric phase lasts for 1-10 (average 3-4) days, and\ngastrointestinal symptoms, such as epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting,\nare frequently reported. The icteric phase begins abruptly, with the\nappearance of jaundice, dark urine and clay-coloured stools. In\nuncomplicated cases these symptoms last 12-15 days, and complete recovery\nusually takes place within 1 month. About half the patients develop fever\nand 2/3 complain of arthralgia.\nClinical studies have shown that elevation of serum alanine\naminotransferase levels occur as a single peak preceding or coinciding with\nthe onset of jaundice, which is similar to most other forms of viral\nhepatitis. In disease-endemic regions, this infection constitutes an\nimportant cause of fulminant hepatic damage. Pregnant women, particularly\nthose in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters, are more frequently affected during\nhepatitis E outbreaks and have a worse outcome. Mortality rates among\npregnant women, especially those infected in the 3rd trimester, range\nbetween 5 and 25 percent. Frequency of abortions, stillbirths and neonatal\ndeaths is also increased among hepatitis E virus-infected pregnant women.\nControl of hepatitis E outbreaks consists predominantly of measures to\ninterrupt water-borne transmission of disease and appropriate education of\nthe population at risk.\nA map of the Democratic Republic of Congo showing the location of Gemena in\nthe north of Equateur Provincec an be accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nHepatitis E - Chad (Eastern)20050822.2477\nHepatitis A & E - India (Hyderabad) 20050328.0894\nHepatitis E - India (Mumbai) 20050107.0044\n2004\n----\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq 20040602.1505\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq (02) 20040924.2642\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) 20040819.2299\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) (02) 20040831.2424\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(03) 20040906.2490\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(04) 20040915.2570\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(05) 20040927.2667\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) 20040810.2209\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (02) 20040827.2398\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (03): background 20040827.2399\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (04) 20040830.2419\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (05) 20040908.2506\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur)(06) 20040929.2689\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nag... 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n...........................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tandaba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gemena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equateur Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Equateur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7981", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E, porcine carriers - Spain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7981", "date": "2006-10-18 00:00:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - CONGO DR (EQUATEUR)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Oct 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Wed 18 Oct 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2c2172e0b4ab34ebf1296bfffd51baaa.htm>\n\nAt least 724 000 people in Equateur Province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC) are at risk after an outbreak of hepatitis E, which has killed\n13 people and infected 341 others since July 2006, an official of the\nUnited Nations World Health Organization (WHO) said.\nHepatitis E is a waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food\nsupplies have been implicated in major outbreaks, according to WHO. A WHO\nepidemiologist, Dr Jean Robert Likofata, said on Tuesday [17 Oct 2006] in\nthe capital, Kinshasa, that 4 health zones around the town of Gemena in\nEquateur were threatened by the disease, which has an incubation period of\nbetween 3 and 8 weeks. He said the whole province was threatened by this\nepidemic because Gemena was an \"epicentre\", as it is a market town,\nfacilitating contact with almost the whole population in the area.\nMoreover, Likofata said cases of hepatitis E had been recorded up to 65 km\nsouthwest in the health zone of Bwamanda; 105 km west in the Tandaba zone\nand at least 44 km northwest in the health zones of Bogose and Nubea. \"This\ndisease is transmitted through contaminated water, especially when hygiene\nis not good when it comes to the washing of hands,\" Likofata said. \"And at\nthis market, which dominates Gemena town, you have businessmen coming from\nall around the province.\"\nLikofata led a medical team to Gemena when the first cases were reported in\nJuly 2006, to inspect samples that were later sent to a laboratory in\nKinshasa. Initially, Likofata said, the outbreak was suspected to be yellow\nfever until the laboratory results confirmed it was hepatitis E. He said\nthose affected initially exhibit flu-like symptoms, with high fever, nausea\nand loss of appetite, which could last a week. The next phase is yellowing\neyes, pale faeces and dark urine consistent with liver disease. There is no\neffective treatment aside from bed-rest and fluid replacement, so\nprevention is key.\nBesides sharing information about the disease's symptoms with staff in the\nmain health centres in Equateur, the medical team also conducted awareness\ncampaigns to inform the public about the importance of hygiene in the\nprevention of hepatitis E.\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Hepatitis E virus, has caused large epidemics of enterically transmitted\nself-limiting acute viral hepatitis throughout the Indian subcontinent,\nsoutheast and central Asia, the Middle East, parts of Africa, and Mexico.\nSeroprevalence surveys indicate that the virus is prevalent elsewhere\nsuggesting the existence of strains of differing virulence.\nHepatitis E is a cause of considerable morbidity and mortality and poses a\nmajor health problem in endemic regions. Hepatitis E epidemics are\nwaterborne outbreaks. During these outbreaks, overall attack rates range\nfrom 1 to 15 percent, being higher among adults (3 to 30 percent) than\namong children (0.2 to 10 percent). The outbreaks are characterized by a\nparticularly high attack rate and mortality among pregnant women. In\nnon-endemic regions, hepatitis E accounts for less than 1 percent of\nreported cases of acute viral hepatitis.\nThe clinical disease in humans is typical of viral hepatitis. The liver\nappears to be the only target organ of infection, and its extrahepatic\nmanifestations have been rare. The incubation period ranges from 15 to 50\ndays. The preicteric phase lasts for 1-10 (average 3-4) days, and\ngastrointestinal symptoms, such as epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting,\nare frequently reported. The icteric phase begins abruptly, with the\nappearance of jaundice, dark urine and clay-coloured stools. In\nuncomplicated cases these symptoms last 12-15 days, and complete recovery\nusually takes place within 1 month. About half the patients develop fever\nand 2/3 complain of arthralgia.\nClinical studies have shown that elevation of serum alanine\naminotransferase levels occur as a single peak preceding or coinciding with\nthe onset of jaundice, which is similar to most other forms of viral\nhepatitis. In disease-endemic regions, this infection constitutes an\nimportant cause of fulminant hepatic damage. Pregnant women, particularly\nthose in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters, are more frequently affected during\nhepatitis E outbreaks and have a worse outcome. Mortality rates among\npregnant women, especially those infected in the 3rd trimester, range\nbetween 5 and 25 percent. Frequency of abortions, stillbirths and neonatal\ndeaths is also increased among hepatitis E virus-infected pregnant women.\nControl of hepatitis E outbreaks consists predominantly of measures to\ninterrupt water-borne transmission of disease and appropriate education of\nthe population at risk.\nA map of the Democratic Republic of Congo showing the location of Gemena in\nthe north of Equateur Provincec an be accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nHepatitis E - Chad (Eastern)20050822.2477\nHepatitis A & E - India (Hyderabad) 20050328.0894\nHepatitis E - India (Mumbai) 20050107.0044\n2004\n----\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq 20040602.1505\nHepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq (02) 20040924.2642\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) 20040819.2299\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) (02) 20040831.2424\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(03) 20040906.2490\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(04) 20040915.2570\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(05) 20040927.2667\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) 20040810.2209\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (02) 20040827.2398\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (03): background 20040827.2399\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (04) 20040830.2419\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (05) 20040908.2506\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur)(06) 20040929.2689\nHepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido) 20041128.3183\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20041127.3172\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (Nag... 20040513.1295\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20040619.1633\nHepatitis E virus - India (West Bengal) 20040423.1129\n...........................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The overall weekly number of reported cases is decreasing in the\ncamps but not in the neighboring villages around Goz Amer camp.\nThe team from the Global Task Force on Cholera Control working in eastern\nChad (see report) will be following up with the implementation of the water\nand sanitation recommendations, including the systematic chlorination of\nall water points, increasing soap distribution, and social mobilization and\nhealth education activities.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The previous WHO update, released on 15 Sep 2004, covering the period up\nto 12 Sep 2004, listed the number of suspected hepatitis E cases as 1292,\nwith 42 deaths. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(04) 20040915.2570\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(03) 20040906.2490\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer)(02) 20040831.2424\nHepatitis E - Chad (Goz Amer) 20040819.2299\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (04) 20040830.2419\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (03): background 20040827.2399\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) (02) 20040827.2398\nHepatitis E - Sudan (Darfur) 20040810.2209\n........................cp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["cholera", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2004-09-16 00:00:00", "2004-09-17 00:00:00", "1442-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-09-15 00:00:00", "2004-09-12 00:00:00", "1292-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Darfur", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206622", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E, waterborne - Iraq (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206622", "date": "2004-04-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - INDIA (WEST BENGAL)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Apr 2004\nFrom: Satadal Das <sdas201@hotmail.com>\nSource: Anandabazar Patrika, Kolkata, Fri 23 Apr 2004 [trans.by S.Das] [edited]\n<http://www.anandabazar.com/calcutta.htm>\n\nIndia: Hepatitis E virus outbreak in Dum Dum district, West Bengal\n----------------------------------------------\nMore than 800 persons have been infected with hepatitis E virus in South\nDum Dum in West Bengal, India, during the past 3 weeks. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\n2002\n----\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\n.................................cp/msp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\n2002\n----\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\n.................................cp/msp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\n2002\n----\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\n.................................cp/msp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\n2002\n----\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\n.................................cp/msp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nHepatitis E virus, water-borne - India (Goa): RFI 20030827.2161\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan 20030803.1906\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (02) 20030804.1918\nHepatitis E virus, wildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996\n2002\n----\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (02) 20020722.4837\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\nHepatitis E virus - Central African Republic (Bangui) 20021010.5515\n.................................cp/msp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph)\n\nAbbott Laboratories Inc. announced it has discovered a new strain of\nhepatitis E virus in the United States. Called HEV-US-1, it is the third\nrecognized hepatitis E virus strain.\nHepatitis E virus is a major contributor to fulminant hepatitis and liver\nfailure in developing nations. Infection is devastating to pregnant women,\nkilling 10-20% of women infected in their third trimester.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Given that this is being called a \"strain\" of hepatitis E virus (family\n_Caliciviridae_, genus _Calicivirus_), I wonder what is the significance of\nthe term \"strain\". Most virologists consider a strain to be a variant of\nsome sort. Are \"strains\" of hepatitis E virus of more epidemiological\nimport than \"strains\" of other viruses? Are all hepatitis E strains\ndetected by routine diagnostic assays or must one have a separate kit for\neach? Do their epidemiologies differ? Do these \"strains\" differ\nsufficiently such that they be given different names? That is, are they\ndifferent viruses? Being an arbovirologist and baseball umpire, I simply do\nnot know the answers to these questions. Could someone enlighten me (us)?\n- Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph)\n\nAbbott Laboratories Inc. announced it has discovered a new strain of\nhepatitis E virus in the United States. Called HEV-US-1, it is the third\nrecognized hepatitis E virus strain.\nHepatitis E virus is a major contributor to fulminant hepatitis and liver\nfailure in developing nations. Infection is devastating to pregnant women,\nkilling 10-20% of women infected in their third trimester.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Given that this is being called a \"strain\" of hepatitis E virus (family\n_Caliciviridae_, genus _Calicivirus_), I wonder what is the significance of\nthe term \"strain\". Most virologists consider a strain to be a variant of\nsome sort. Are \"strains\" of hepatitis E virus of more epidemiological\nimport than \"strains\" of other viruses? Are all hepatitis E strains\ndetected by routine diagnostic assays or must one have a separate kit for\neach? Do their epidemiologies differ? Do these \"strains\" differ\nsufficiently such that they be given different names? That is, are they\ndifferent viruses? Being an arbovirologist and baseball umpire, I simply do\nnot know the answers to these questions. Could someone enlighten me (us)?\n- Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph)\n\nAbbott Laboratories Inc. announced it has discovered a new strain of\nhepatitis E virus in the United States. Called HEV-US-1, it is the third\nrecognized hepatitis E virus strain.\nHepatitis E virus is a major contributor to fulminant hepatitis and liver\nfailure in developing nations. Infection is devastating to pregnant women,\nkilling 10-20% of women infected in their third trimester.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Given that this is being called a \"strain\" of hepatitis E virus (family\n_Caliciviridae_, genus _Calicivirus_), I wonder what is the significance of\nthe term \"strain\". Most virologists consider a strain to be a variant of\nsome sort. Are \"strains\" of hepatitis E virus of more epidemiological\nimport than \"strains\" of other viruses? Are all hepatitis E strains\ndetected by routine diagnostic assays or must one have a separate kit for\neach? Do their epidemiologies differ? Do these \"strains\" differ\nsufficiently such that they be given different names? That is, are they\ndifferent viruses? Being an arbovirologist and baseball umpire, I simply do\nnot know the answers to these questions. Could someone enlighten me (us)?\n- Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph)\n\nAbbott Laboratories Inc. announced it has discovered a new strain of\nhepatitis E virus in the United States. Called HEV-US-1, it is the third\nrecognized hepatitis E virus strain.\nHepatitis E virus is a major contributor to fulminant hepatitis and liver\nfailure in developing nations. Infection is devastating to pregnant women,\nkilling 10-20% of women infected in their third trimester.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Given that this is being called a \"strain\" of hepatitis E virus (family\n_Caliciviridae_, genus _Calicivirus_), I wonder what is the significance of\nthe term \"strain\". Most virologists consider a strain to be a variant of\nsome sort. Are \"strains\" of hepatitis E virus of more epidemiological\nimport than \"strains\" of other viruses? Are all hepatitis E strains\ndetected by routine diagnostic assays or must one have a separate kit for\neach? Do their epidemiologies differ? Do these \"strains\" differ\nsufficiently such that they be given different names? That is, are they\ndifferent viruses? Being an arbovirologist and baseball umpire, I simply do\nnot know the answers to these questions. Could someone enlighten me (us)?\n- Mod.CHC]\n......................................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph)\n\nAbbott Laboratories Inc. announced it has discovered a new strain of\nhepatitis E virus in the United States. Called HEV-US-1, it is the third\nrecognized hepatitis E virus strain.\nHepatitis E virus is a major contributor to fulminant hepatitis and liver\nfailure in developing nations. Infection is devastating to pregnant women,\nkilling 10-20% of women infected in their third trimester.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Given that this is being called a \"strain\" of hepatitis E virus (family\n_Caliciviridae_, genus _Calicivirus_), I wonder what is the significance of\nthe term \"strain\". Most virologists consider a strain to be a variant of\nsome sort. Are \"strains\" of hepatitis E virus of more epidemiological\nimport than \"strains\" of other viruses? Are all hepatitis E strains\ndetected by routine diagnostic assays or must one have a separate kit for\neach? Do their epidemiologies differ? Do these \"strains\" differ\nsufficiently such that they be given different names? That is, are they\ndifferent viruses? Being an arbovirologist and baseball umpire, I simply do\nnot know the answers to these questions.
